revision.text:
{{POV|date=May 2013}}
On November 7, 2012, over 200 houses were torched in Natham, old and new Kondampatti and Annanagar [[Dalit]] colonies in [[Dharmapuri district]], [[Tamil Nadu]]. When a [[Vanniyar]] girl from Sellankottai village, and a [[Dalit]] boy, from the neighbouring Dalit colony of Natham, fled due to parental opposition to get married, a caste panchayat held on the morning of November 7 by leaders from both communities ruled that the girl be returned to her family. Distraught at her decision to stay with her husband, her father, who worked at a cooperative bank, allegedly committed suicide by hanging himself. The discovery of his body later that day is said to have provoked a 1,500-strong mob to rampage through Natham and two smaller Dalit settlements, Kondampatti and Anna Nagar, where it set ablaze over 200 houses, damaged at least 50 others, and allegedly looted valuables and cash worth lakhs of rupees. The mob rampaged for four hours and was brought under control after arrest of 90 men and an additional deployment of 1000 policemen.<ref name=arrest>{{cite news|author=K A Shaji |author2=V Senthil Kumaran |author3=Karthick S|first=TNN|title=Inter-caste marriage sparks riot in Tamil Nadu district, 148 dalit houses torched|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-09/india/35015844_1_dalit-houses-dalit-youth-dalit-boy|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=Times of India|date=9 November 2012}}</ref>
While [[S. Ramadoss|Ramadoss]], belonging to [[Pattali Makkal Katchi|PMK]] party, had rubbished allegations that his party orchestrated the incident, many Dalits believe otherwise. Also, his party is said to have fomented tension between Vanniyars and Dalits by publicly condemning marriages between the two.<ref name="indianexpress.com">http://www.indianexpress.com/news/love-and-violence-in-dharmapuri/1035856/2o</ref> However, there is no evidence that the PMK played any role in the attack.<ref name="indianexpress.com"/>
Many of the victims had blamed the fecklessness of the police and the district administration as this was a planned incident where a caste mob had been mobilised from 22 neighbouring villages. Though around 300 policemen were present on the spot anticipating trouble, they failed to control the violent gathering as the mob was eight times higher than the number of deployed forces.<ref>http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-08/coimbatore/34993610_1_dalit-boy-dalit-houses-caste-violence</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/love-and-violence-in-dharmapuri/1035856/4|title=Love and violence in Dharmapuri - Indian Express|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> The Sub-inspector of Police, belonging to same caste of boy, and the constables responsible for maintaining peace in the area have since been transferred or suspended.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Background== The population of [[Vanniyars]], an intermediate caste inhabiting parts of northern Tamil Nadu, is estimated at 12-13per cent, while the [[ Adidravidas]] ([[Dalits]]) constitute about 11.5 per cent. With the collapse of [[Naxalism]], the people, once monolithic in their opposition to untouchability and discrimination, were now lured by caste identities and the promise of power. Thus began a disquieting era where Dalits were made vulnerable by radicalised groups and Vanniyars turned sanctimonious about their perceived position in society. So, there were regularly clashes between the Vanniyars and Dalits.<ref>{{cite web|last=Warrier|first=Shobha|title=The Rediff Interview/R Thirumalvalavan|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2002/aug/12inter.htm|work=Rediff|publisher=Rediff|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> In April 2012, [[Pattali Makkal Katchi]] party [[Member of the Legislative Assembly (India)|MLA]], [[Kaduvetti Guru]] incited caste [[fanaticism]] when he asked the members of community to kill men from other community who marry Vanniyar community women at a Vanniyar youth meeting held in [[Mamallapuram]].<ref>{{cite web|author =Chakra|title=வெட்டி தள்ளுங்க..: சாதி உணர்வை தூண்டிய காடுவெட்டி குரு மீது மாமல்லபுரம் போலீஸ் வழக்குப்பதிவு|url=http://tamil.oneindia.in/news/2012/05/17/tamilnadu-case-filed-against-kaduvetti-guru-mamallapuram-154122.html|publisher=OneIndia|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2924/stories/20121214292404000.htm|title=Double disadvantage|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513054044/http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2924/stories/20121214292404000.htm|archivedate=13 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-why-i-want-to-ask-disturbing-questions-and-say-the-unsaid/20121128.htm#5|title=Why I want to ask disturbing questions and say the unsaid|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327012054/http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-why-i-want-to-ask-disturbing-questions-and-say-the-unsaid/20121128.htm|archivedate=27 March 2016|deadurl=no|quote=...Kaduvetti Guru has repeatedly been broadcasting this message. At a Chitra Pournami event in Mahabalipuram addressing Vanniyar youth, Guru openly exhorted that men of other castes marrying Vanniyar women should be killed.}}</ref>
==Aftermath== As many as 268 dwellings of Dalits (of the [[Adi Dravida]] community) near Naikkankottai in [[Dharmapuri district]] were torched by the higher-caste group.<ref name="Toi-Incident">{{cite news|title=Dalit houses torched, caste violence in Dharmapuri|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-08/coimbatore/34993610_1_dalit-boy-dalit-houses-caste-violence|accessdate=26 April 2013|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=8 November 2012}}</ref> The victims have alleged that ‘systematic destruction’ of their properties and livelihood resources has taken place. Around 1500 who were homeless after the incident were put up in a ground nearby and were provided food and clothing <ref>{{cite news|title=தர்மபுரி: வீடு எரிக்கப்பட்ட தாழ்த்தப்பட்ட மக்கள் வெட்ட வெளியில்|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/tamil/india/2012/11/121109_dharmapuri.shtml|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=BBC Tamil|date=9 November 2012}}</ref> and also sanctioned [[Indian rupee|Rs]] 50,000 as relief from Tamil Nadu Chief Minister’s Relief Fund.<ref name="HC-first-response">{{cite news|last=SANGAMESWARAN|first=K. T.|title=Dharmapuri incident serious: HC|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/dharmapuri-incident-serious-hc/article4082173.ece|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=10 November 2012}}</ref> The affected people staged a fast demanding Chief Minister to visit the affected areas and to increase compensation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-29/coimbatore/35434504_1_hunger-strike-dalits-dharmapuri |title=Dharmapuri dalits on hunger strike, wants CM to visit, CBI probe |publisher=The Times Of India |date=2012-11-29 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref>
==Reactions== * Members of [[National Commission for Scheduled Castes]] after visiting the colonies blamed the attitude of the state police for failing to control the violence and stated that rise in status of Dalits are not tolerated by dominant caste Hindus which results in incidents of violence.<ref name="SC-Panel-comment">{{cite web|url=http://newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/article1356312.ece |title=SC panel blames police for Dharmapuri violence |publisher=The New Indian Express |date=2012-11-27 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> They also alleged that the violence was a well-organized and planned attack on Dalits and not a spontaneous anguish over a single incident of suicide.<ref name="SC-Panel-Organized">{{cite web|author =R. Arivanantham |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/attack-on-dalits-was-planned-national-commission-for-scs/article4090674.ece |title=Attack on Dalits was planned: National Commission for SCs |publisher=The Hindu |date=2012-11-12 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> * [[Viduthalai Chiruthaigal Katchi]], a Dalit-based political party demanded a [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]] probe into the incident as it did not have faith in local police inquiry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/tamil-nadu/vck-wants-cbi-probe-into-dharmapuri-violence_812808.html |title=VCK wants CBI probe into Dharmapuri violence |publisher=Zee News |date=2012-11-25 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> VCK president [[Thol. Thirumavalavan]] compared the incidents to 1990s Kodiyankulam violence where the main reason for the violence was upward mobility of Dalits in economic, educational, political fronts.<ref>{{cite web|author =D. Karthikeyan |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/dalits-being-targeted-because-of-their-upward-economic-mobility-say-leaders/article4125413.ece |title=Dalits being targeted because of their upward economic mobility, say leaders |publisher=The Hindu |date=2012-11-23 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> * [[Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam]] party constituted a fact finding committee came out with a report which stated {{Quotation|The attack was a planned one. Inter-caste love marriage was not the sole reason behind it. Rather, the attack was the result of a chain of events. The PMK functionaries are found to have instigated and carried out the attacks. While the police is yet to arrest all the culprits behind the attack, they have booked a few innocents who are not connected with the incident}} It also blamed the state government for not taking enough steps to restore normalcy or implementing relief measures.<ref name="DMK-fact-report">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/dmk-factfinding-committee-points-a-finger-at-pmk/article4124002.ece |title=DMK fact-finding committee points a finger at PMK |publisher=The Hindu |date=2012-11-23 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref>
* [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] MLAs [[K. Balakrishnan (CPI-M)|K. Balakrishnan]], [[P. Dillibabu]] and K. Bheema Rao visited the affected people to console and provide relief materials. They told the attack which seem to be well planned could not be prevented because of Intelligence failure and failure to keep a check on Kangaroo courts and demanded police to take action against those responsible under [[Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989|SC-ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/cpi-m-mlas-visit-dalit-colonies/article4085709.ece |title=CPI (M) MLAs visit Dalit colonies |publisher=The Hindu |date=2012-11-11 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> * [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] in Tamil Nadu said that the government has failed to check increasing incidents of breakdown of law and order and the police are not given full power to deal with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/tamil-nadu/people-will-take-to-streets-if-govt-fails-to-check_810243.html |title=People will take to streets if govt fails to check |publisher=Zee News |date=2012-11-09 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> * PMK founder [[S. Ramadoss]] came out with 'staged love marriages' happening in the state where Dalit men lure Vanniyar women claiming to be in love and later duping them, ask for a ransom after marriage through Kangaroo courts. This was seen as a budding parallel to [[Love Jihad]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/dharmapuri-violence-why-tn-could-become-a-hotbed-for-love-jihad-543446.html|title=PMK's anti-Dalit rant in TN resembles Kerala's 'love jihad' theory - Firstpost|date=3 December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> He also stated the mob that indulged in violence was cutting across castes / party lines unlike mentioned in sections of media / parties as mainly consisting of Vanniyar / PMK men.<ref>{{cite web|last=News |first=Express |url=http://newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/article1343977.ece |title=Ramadoss joins issue with VCK on Dharmapuri violence |publisher=The New Indian Express |date= |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> He also formed an alliance of caste Hindu organizations against Dalit assertion.<ref>{{cite web|author =B. Kolappan |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/ramadoss-consolidates-intermediate-caste-groups-against-dalits/article4156999.ece |title=Ramadoss consolidates intermediate caste groups against Dalits |publisher=The Hindu |date=2012-12-02 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-12-22/coimbatore/35968581_1_kongu-vellala-goundergal-peravai-inter-caste-marriages-vanniyars |title=Gounder groups join Paattali Makkal Katchi's platform against inter-caste marriages |publisher=The Times Of India |date=2012-12-22 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> asking for amendment to prevent the misuse of [[Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989|Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe (Prevention of Atrocities) Act]] and a ban on intercaste marriages which was opposed by VCK and rationalist groups like [[Dravidar Kazhagam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/tamil-nadu-dharamapuri-violence-inter-caste-marriges/1/230066.html |title=In Tamil Nadu, after caste violence cupid enters political discourse |publisher=India Today |date=2012-11-20 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref>
==Probe and court proceedings== The Tamil Nadu government transferred the probe from local police to [[Crime Branch CID]].<ref>{{cite web|author =PTI |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/dharmapuri-violence-probe-transferred-to-cbcid/article4102280.ece |title=Dharmapuri violence: probe transferred to CB-CID |publisher=The Hindu |date=2012-11-16 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> More than 90 persons were arrested and cases were filed against over 200 people.<ref name=arrest/> The [[Madras High Court]] has stated the incident as serious and instructed the state authorities to submit a status report and the counter affidavit on that date.<ref name="HC-first-response"/> A PIL was filed seeking the suspension of [[District collector]] and [[Superintendent of police (India)|Superintendent of police]] for inaction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-22/chennai/35302225_1_dalit-families-inter-caste-marriage-caste-leaders |title=Dharmapuri violence: PIL seeks suspension of collector and SP |publisher=The Times Of India |date=2012-11-22 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> On 3 December 2012, The district collector told the court that adequate relief measures were provided to victims and steps have been taken to maintain law and order in the area. The Superintendent of Police said cases have been registered and 142 people have been arrested.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/dharmapuri-violence-dalit-victims-provided-with-relief-543974.html|title=Dharmapuri violence: Dalit victims provided with relief - Firstpost|date=3 December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> High Court termed the relief insufficient and ordered the state to provide a relief of 7.32 crore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/hc-terms-tn-relief-for-dalits-in-dharmapuri-insufficient/1057600/ |title=HC terms TN relief for Dalits in Dharmapuri insufficient |publisher=Indian Express |date=2013-01-11 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> A fresh PIL was filed asking for effective monitoring of offenses under SC-ST act and transfer the probe to [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]]. The petition was posted along with the other petitions in the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.in.com/news/current-affairs/pil-seeks-effective-monitoring-of-offences-against-scssts-50169314-in-1.html |title=PIL seeks effective monitoring of offences against SCs/STs |publisher=In.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> Tamil Nadu govt then declared solatium to individuals were ready to the tune of 7.32 crore as per court order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/dharmapuri-violence-tn-govt-tells-hc-solatium-is-ready-113013100630_1.html |title=Dharmapuri violence: TN govt tells HC solatium is ready |publisher=Business Standard |date=2013-01-31 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> On Feb 9 2013, 91 people including some of whom who were falsely arrested for passing by near the violence area were let off and asked to appear before the CBCID.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newindianexpress.com/states/tamil_nadu/article1456013.ece |title=91 held for Dharmapuri violence walk free |publisher=The New Indian Express |date=2013-02-09 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> On March 29, the high court gave bail to 28 accused in the case.<ref>{{cite web|author = |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130329/news-current-affairs/article/hc-grants-bail-28-accused-dharmapuri-caste-violence |title=HC grants bail to 28 accused in Dharmapuri caste violence |publisher=Deccan Chronicle |date=2012-11-07 |accessdate=2013-05-16}}</ref> ==See also== * [[Dalit]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dharmapuri violence}} [[Category:History of Tamil Nadu (1947–present)]] [[Category:Caste-related violence in India]] [[Category:Dharmapuri district]] [[Category:Arson in India]] [[Category:2012 in India]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in India]] [[Category:Dalit history]] [[Category:November 2012 events]] [[Category:Honor killing]]

{{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox military conflict | conflict = 2013 Republican Guard headquarters clashes | partof = the [[Post-coup unrest in Egypt (2013–14)]] | image = | caption = | date = {{start date|2013|07|08|df=yes}} | place = [[Republican Guard (Egypt)|Republican Guard Headquarters]]
[[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]], [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] | coordinates = {{coord|30|04|51|N|31|19|00|E|region:EG_type:event_scale:50000|display=inline,title}} | territory = | result = | status = | combatants_header = | combatant1 = Pro-[[Mohamed Morsi|Morsi]] protesters{{cite news|title=Dozens Die in Clashes Outside Cairo's Republican Guard HQ|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/07/08/199929861/the-latest-news-from-egypt|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=[[NPR]]|date=8 July 2013|author=David Greene|author2=Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson}}
''Supported by:''
[[File:Muslim Brotherhood Emblem.jpg|20px]] [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]]{{cite news|title=At least 54 killed in clashes at Cairo Republican Guard headquarters|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/07/08/at-least-5-dead-in-new-egypt-clashes/|accessdate=11 July 2013|newspaper=[[Fox News]]|date=11 July 2013}} | combatant2 = [[File:Coat of arms of Egypt (Official).svg|20px]] [[Egyptian Armed Forces]]
[[File:Republican Guard Egypt.png|20px]] [[Republican Guard (Egypt)|Republican Guard]] | commander1 = [[Mohammed Badie]] {{small|([[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt#Leadership|Supreme Guide]] of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]])}} | commander2 = [[Abdul Fatah al-Sisi]] {{small|([[List of Ministers of Defence of Egypt|Commander-in-Chief & Defense Minister]])}} | units1 = | units2 = [[Republican Guard (Egypt)|Egyptian Republican Guard]]
[[Egyptian Army]] | strength1 = Unknown | strength2 = Unknown | casualties1 = 51 protesters killed | casualties2 = 3 military and security personnel killed | notes = | campaignbox = }} On the morning of 8 July 2013 at the [[Republican Guard (Egypt)|Republican Guard]] headquarters in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] there was a clash between protesters seeking the return of deposed [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Mohamed Morsi]], and the military, who were protecting the institution. At least 51 protesters seeking the return of Morsi to power were killed and more than 435 injured in the clashes, in what has been deemed as a massacre by the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] and those opposed to the recent [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|coup d'état]].{{cite news|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/07/08/19347026-51-dead-435-hurt-in-clashes-near-pro-morsi-sit-in|title=51 dead, 435 hurt in clashes near pro-Morsi sit-in|date=8 July 2013|publisher=nbcnews}} Amnesty International has condemned the military's disproportionate use of force, with a spokesperson stating, "Even if some protesters used violence, the response was disproportionate and led to the loss of life and injury among peaceful protesters."{{cite web|title=Egypt: Damning evidence points to security forces’ failures|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/for-media/press-releases/egypt-damning-evidence-points-security-forces-failures-2013-07-09|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=10 July 2013}} ==Incident== According to some witnesses, the military opened fire without provocation towards the end of morning prayers, immediately using live ammunition and shooting to kill. [[Gehad El-Haddad]], the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]]'s spokesman, claimed that the military opened fire at the protesters while they were praying in front of the Republican Guard and staging a peaceful sit-in. One witness claimed that protestors had their backs to the Republic Guard building, as they were praying towards Mecca.{{cite news|title=Egypt coup: July 8 as it happened|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/10166063/Egypt-coup-July-8-as-it-happened.html|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=8 July 2013}} Others claimed that the incident was after prayers.{{cite news|title=Cairo clashes: 'I saw both sides shooting at each other from my balcony'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/10167263/Cairo-clashes-I-saw-both-sides-shooting-at-each-other-from-my-balcony.html|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=8 July 2013}} Some protestors claimed that [[Law enforcement in Egypt|police officer]] Mohamed el-Mesairy was sheltering in his parked car when he was killed by military gunfire striking the car.[[New York Times]], 8 July 2013, [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/09/world/middleeast/egypt.html?pagewanted=2&_r=0&hp Army Kills 51, Deepening Crisis in Egypt] According to the military, a "terrorist group" tried to storm the Republican Guard headquarters and that it had retaliated by opening fire at the attackers. A military spokesman reported that an officer was killed and six troops were injured before adding that 42 troops were injured and eight were in critical condition. An amateur video recording showed people holding guns from the side of the protesters during daylight.{{cite news|title="Video" masked gunmen between supporters of Morsi during clashes "Republican guard"|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/1928316|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=8 July 2013|language=Arabic}} ==Investigation== Preliminary investigations showed that the crime scene contained firearms, ammunition, [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] membership cards, explosives that contained pieces of glass, smoke grenades and a document that contained a list of names with monetary values next to it.{{cite news|last=Qaraa|first=Ibrahim|title=Prosecution: A list of names with the sums of money received at the location of the "Clashes of the Republican Guard"|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/1928746|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|language=Arabic|date=8 July 2013}} The army said it had arrested over 200 people, with "large quantities of firearms, ammunition and Molotov cocktails".[[The Guardian]], 8 July 2013, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/08/egypt-braced-violence-morsi-supporters Egypt braced for more violence after 'massacre' of Morsi supporters] ==Domestic response== * The interim presidency ordered the formation of a judicial committee to investigate the killings at the "raid against the Republican Guard headquarters".{{cite news|title=Egypt presidency forms judicial committee to investiage Rep. Guard killings|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/76014.aspx|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=8 July 2013}} * [[Prime Minister of Egypt|Prime Minister]] [[Hesham Qandil]] resigned from office effective immediately in protest of the bloodshed.{{Cite web |url=http://www.turkishweekly.net/2013/07/09/news/egypt-pm-qandil-addresses-resignation-to-morsi-slams-military-coup/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=17 June 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314230111/http://www.turkishweekly.net/2013/07/09/news/egypt-pm-qandil-addresses-resignation-to-morsi-slams-military-coup/ |archive-date=14 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} * The [[National Salvation Front (Egypt)|National Salvation Front]] condemned "all acts of violence" and called for an investigation over the incident.{{cite news|title=Egypt's National Salvation Front condemns Rep. Guard HQ violence|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/76005/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-National-Salvation-Front-condemns-Rep-Guard.aspx|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=8 July 2013}} * The [[Nour Party]] objected to the incident and stated that they would stop participating in the political transition. * The [[Freedom and Justice Party (Egypt)|Freedom and Justice Party]] called for "the international community and international groups and all the free people of the world to intervene to stop further massacres [...] and prevent a new Syria in the Arab world."{{cite news|title=Muslim Brotherhood calls for Egypt uprising|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/07/20137872812532255.html|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=8 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/1928331|title="Freedom and Justice" asks for international intervention "to avoid Egypt transformation to Syria"|language=Arabic|publisher=Al Masry Al youm|date=8 July 2013}} * Former presidential candidate and [[Strong Egypt Party]] leader [[Abdel Moneim Aboul Fotouh]] called for interim President [[Adly Mansour]] to step down in response to the clashes.{{cite news|title=UPDATE 5: 42 die in clashes between Egypt army and pro-Morsi protesters|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/75982/Egypt/Politics-/UPDATE---die-in-clashes-between-Egypt-army-and-pro.aspx|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=8 July 2013}} ==International response== * Germany – The Foreign Ministry said that it was "dismayed" over reports of the violence and called for a "speedy clarification" by an independent body into the incident.{{cite news|title=Governments condemn shootings in Egypt|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-wires/20130708/eu-egypt-reaction-glance/|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=[[Huffingtonpost]]|date=8 July 2013}} * Iran – The Foreign Ministry published a statement about recent conflicts in Egypt: "Expressing concern about Egypt's internal conflicts, we stressed the need for strict adherence to the democratic process in this country."[http://www.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=13920416001353 Iran's reaction to the Egypt's clashes] * Palestine [[Hamas]]{{who|date=July 2013}} expressed "extreme pain and grief for the falling of these victims".{{cite news|title=World governments condemn shootings in Egypt|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/76020/Egypt/Politics-/World-governments-condemn-shootings-in-Egypt.aspx|accessdate=8 July 2013|newspaper=Ahram Online|date=8 July 2013}} * Qatar – Qatar{{who|date=July 2013}} expressed "great concern" over the incident. * Turkey – Foreign Minister [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]] wrote on ''Twitter'': "I strongly condemn the massacre that took place at morning prayers in the name of basic human values." * United Kingdom – Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] said: "There is an urgent need for calm and restraint". ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/interactive/2013/jul/18/cairo-republican-guard-shooting-full-story Killing in Cairo: the full story of the Republican Guards' club shootings], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 18 July 2013 {{Egyptian Revolution of 2011|state=collapsed}} [[Category:2013 Egyptian coup d'état]] [[Category:2013 in Egypt]] [[Category:2013 protests]] [[Category:Egyptian crisis (2011–14)]] [[Category:Protest-related deaths]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Egypt]]

revision.text:
{{chembox | Name = APN | ImageFile = 3-arylpropiolonitriles.png | OtherNames = 3-arylpropynenitrile, 3-arylpropiolonitrile }} '''3-Arylpropiolonitriles (APN)''' belong to a class of electron-deficient alkyne derivatives substituted by two electron-withdrawing groups – a [[nitrile]] and an [[aryl]] moieties. Such activation results in improved selectivity towards highly reactive thiol-containing molecules, namely [[cysteine]] residues in [[protein]]s. APN-based modification of proteins was reported to surpass several important drawbacks of existing strategies in [[bioconjugation]], notably the presence of side reactions with other nucleophilic amino acid residues and the relative instability of the resulting bioconjugates in the blood stream.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Bioconjugate Chem |author1=Koniev, O. |author2=Leriche, G.|author3=Nothisen, M.|author4=Remy, J.-S.|author5=Strub, J.-M.|author6=Schaeffer-Reiss, C.|author7=Dorsselaer, A.|author8=Baati, R.|author9=Wagner, A. | title = Selective Irreversible Chemical Tagging of Cysteine with 3-Arylpropiolonitriles | volume = 25 | pages = 202–206 | year = 2014 | doi = 10.1021/bc400469d | issue = 2}}</ref> The latter drawback is especially important for the preparation of [[targeted therapies]], such as [[antibody-drug conjugates]].<ref name="Senter2014">{{cite journal | journal = Bioconjugate Chem |author1=Lyon, R.P. |author2=Setter, J.R.|author3=Bovee, T.D.|author4=Doronina, S.O.|author5=Hunter, J.H.|author6=Anderson M.E.|author7=Balasubramanian, C.L.|author8=Duniho, S.M. |author9=Leiske, C.I. |author10=Li, F. |author11=Senter, P.D. | title = Self-hydrolyzing maleimides improve the stability and pharmacological properties of antibody-drug conjugates | volume = 32 | pages = 1059–1062 | year = 2014 | doi = 10.1038/nbt.2968 | issue = 10}}</ref><ref name="Kolodych2015">{{cite journal | journal = Bioconjugate Chem |author1=Kolodych, S. |author2=Koniev, O.|author3=Baatarkhuu, Z.|author4=Bonnefoy, J.-Y.|author5=Debaene, F.|author6=Chienférani, S.|author7=Dorsselaer, A.|author8=Wagner, A. | title = CBTF: new amine-to-thiol coupling reagent for preparation of antibody conjugates with increased plasma stability | volume = 26 | pages = 197–200 | year = 2015 | doi = 10.1021/bc400469d | issue = 2}}</ref>
==Synthesis== The synthesis of 3-arylpropiolonitriles has been the subject of several studies.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Canadian Journal of Chemistry |author1=Shu, F. |author2=Zheng, Q.|author3=Dong, W.|author4=Peng, Z.|author5=An, D.| title = One-pot synthesis of propynoates and propynenitriles| volume = 95 | pages = 144–148 | year = 2017 |issue = 2| doi = 10.1139/cjc-2016-0181}}</ref> The most elaborated and often used approach is based on MnO2-mediated free radical oxidation of the corresponding propargylic alcohols obtained using [[Sonogashira coupling]] of the corresponding iodo-derivative in the presence of [[ammonia]] (Figure 1).<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Synlett |author1=McAllister, G.D. |author2=Wilfred, C.D.|author3=Taylor, R.J.K.| title = Tandem oxidation processes: The direct conversion of activated alcohols into nitriles | volume = 8 |issue=8 | pages = 1291–1292 | year = 2002 | doi = 10.1055/s-2002-32950}}</ref>
[[File:Figure 1. Synthesis of substituted 3-arylpropiononitriles (APN).tif|frameless|Figure 3. Bioconjugation strategies for tyrosine residues|475x475px]]
==Applications in biotechnology== In [[bioconjugation]] (forming a stable covalent link between a biomolecule and a functional payloads, such as fluorescent dyes, cytotoxic agents, or tracers), linking of the payload was classically achieved using [[maleimide]] heterobifunctional reagents (for example, see [[succinimidyl 4-(N-maleimidomethyl)cyclohexane-1-carboxylate|SMCC]]).<ref name="Hermanson2013">{{cite book |last=Hermanson |first=Greg |title=Bioconjugate Techniques |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/book/9780123822390 |publisher= Elsevier |pages=299–339 |isbn=978-0-12-382239-0}}</ref> However, when administered into living organisms, maleimide-containing bioconjugates were found to be relatively unstable and lose the payload in the blood circulation due to reversibility of the addition reaction between maleimide moiety and cysteine residue of a protein (retro Michael addition).<ref name="Senter2014" /> Due to increased stability of [[Bioconjugation|bioconjugates]] obtained with analogous APN-based payloads (a schematic reaction is shown in the '''Figure 2''' below),<ref name="Kolodych2015"/> their use is often preferable when high selectivity and biostability are especially important: namely for the preparation of [[Antibody-drug conjugate|antibody−drug conjugates]] and other [[Biopharmaceutical|biologics]]. Standard procedure for APN protein labeling consists in incubation of a protein containing free [[cysteine]] residues with an APN-functionalized probe in [[Phosphate-buffered saline|PBS buffer]] at pH 7.5-9.0 at room temperature for 2–12 hours, followed by an optional step of purification of the resulting bioconjugate using [[size exclusion chromatography]] or [[ultrafiltration]].
[[File:APN reaction with protein.tif|frameless|Figure 2. Schematic reaction of APN-functionalized probe with a protein|400x400px]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Arylpropiolonitriles, 3-}} [[Category:Biotechnology]] [[Category:Nitriles]] [[Category:Alkynes]] [[Category:Aromatic compounds]]

{{redirect|Human longevity|the company|Human Longevity}} The '''anti-aging movement''' is a [[social movement]] devoted to eliminating or reversing [[aging]], or reducing the effects of it.<ref name="Mykytyn">{{Cite journal|last=Mykytyn|first=Courtney Everts|date=February 2006|title=Anti-aging medicine: A patient/practitioner movement to redefine aging|journal=Social Science & Medicine|volume=62|issue=3|pages=643–653|doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2005.06.021|issn=0277-9536|pmid=16040177}}<!--| accessdate = 2009-12-05 --></ref><ref name=EthicsHealthPolicyAndAntiAgingChapter3>{{cite book|last1=Vincent|first1=John|editor1-last=Schermer|editor1-first=Maartje|editor2-last=Pinxten|editor2-first=Wim|title=Ethics, Health Policy and (Anti-) Aging: Mixed Blessings|date=2013|publisher=Springer Netherlands|isbn=978-94-007-3870-6|page=30|chapter=The Anti-Aging Movement|quote=There have been a number of social movements associated with the reappraisal of age-based social categories in the last thirty years. Two such developments are the focus of this chapter. They are the Third Age movement and the Anti-aging movement. These movements present contrasting perspectives on the culturally devalued status of old age; the former seeks to celebrate old age, the latter to eliminate it.}}</ref> A substantial portion of the attention of the movement is on the possibilities for [[life extension]], but there is also interest in techniques such as [[cosmetic surgery]] which ameliorate the effects of aging rather than delay or defeat it.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Landman|first1=Beth|title=The Future of Forever Young: 12 of the Latest Anti-Aging Treatments You Can Now Try|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/future-forever-young-12-latest-anti-aging-treatments-you-can-try-952805|accessdate=27 December 2016|date=12 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228033708/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/future-forever-young-12-latest-anti-aging-treatments-you-can-try-952805|archivedate=28 December 2016|df=}}</ref>
Two popular proponents of the anti-aging movement include [[Ray Kurzweil]], who says humanity can defeat aging through the advance of [[technology]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Chasing Immortality—The Technology of Eternal Life |author=Craig Hamilton |url=http://www.enlightennext.org/magazine/j30/kurzweil.asp |accessdate=May 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606134650/http://www.enlightennext.org/magazine/j30/kurzweil.asp |archivedate=June 6, 2012 }}</ref> and [[Aubrey De Grey]], who says that the human body is a very complicated machine and thus, can be repaired indefinitely.<ref name=SingularitySymposiumDeGray>{{cite web|title=Who is Aubrey de Grey?|url=http://www.singularitysymposium.com/aubrey-de-grey.html|website=Singularity Symposium|quote=Maybe it is because of his background in computer science that Dr. de Grey perceives the human body as a very complicated machine. Therefore, he argues that aging is primarily an engineering problem. Thus once we grasp all the finer details of our biological structure then the problem of aging becomes one of maintenance and just like today we are capable to maintain vintage cars or airplanes indefinitely he believes that eventually we'll be able to do so with our bodies.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502084514/http://www.singularitysymposium.com/aubrey-de-grey.html|archivedate=2012-05-02|df=}}</ref> Other scientists and significant contributors to the movement include molecular biologists, geneticists, and biomedical gerontologists such as [[Gary Ruvkun]], [[Cynthia Kenyon]], and [[Arthur D. Levinson]]. However, figures in the [[gerontology]] community in 2003 tried to distance their research from the perceived pseudoscience of the movement.<ref name=BinstockGerontologist2003WarOnAntiAging>{{cite journal|last1=Binstock|first1=Robert|title=The War on "Anti-Aging Medicine"|journal=The Gerontologist|date=2003|volume=43|issue=1|pages=4–14|doi=10.1093/geront/43.1.4|url=http://gerontologist.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/1/4.full|quote=Leading members of the gerontological community have recently launched a war on anti-aging medicine, seeking to discredit what they judge to be fraudulent and harmful products and therapies, and to distinguish their research from what they regard as the pseudoscience of the anti-aging movement.|pmid=12604740|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151202050907/http://gerontologist.oxfordjournals.org/content/43/1/4.full|archivedate=2015-12-02|df=}}</ref>
==Anti-aging medicine== {{Main|Anti-aging medicine}} Anti-aging medicine has become a budding and rapidly growing [[Specialty (medicine)|medical specialty]] as physicians who initially sought treatment for themselves have received training and [[Board certification|certification]] in its practice<ref name=Mykytyn/> by organizations such as the [[American Academy of Anti-Aging Medicine]] (A4M).
===Human growth hormone===
Central to anti-aging medicine is administration of [[human growth hormone]].<ref>Ronald Klatz, ''Grow Young with HGH: The Amazing Medically Proven Plan to Reverse Aging'' Harper Paperbacks (May 8, 1998), trade paperback, 400 pages {{ISBN|0-06-098434-1}} {{ISBN|978-0060984342}}</ref> Clinical studies have shown that low-dose growth hormone (GH) treatment for adults with GH deficiency changes the body composition by increasing [[muscle]] mass, decreasing fat mass, and increasing [[bone]] density and muscle strength. It also improves [[cardiovascular]] parameters (i.e. decrease of [[LDL cholesterol]]) and affects the quality of life without significant side effects.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Alexopoulou O, Abs R, Maiter D |title=Treatment of adult growth hormone deficiency: who, why and how? A review |journal=Acta Clinica Belgica |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=13–22 |year=2010 |pmid=20373593 |doi=10.1179/acb.2010.002}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ahmad AM, Hopkins MT, Thomas J, Ibrahim H, Fraser WD, Vora JP |title=Body composition and quality of life in adults with growth hormone deficiency; effects of low-dose growth hormone replacement |journal=Clinical Endocrinology |volume=54 |issue=6 |pages=709–17 |date=June 2001 |pmid=11422104 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2265.2001.01275.x}}</ref><ref name=pmid10971102>{{cite journal |vauthors=Savine R, Sönksen P |title=Growth hormone - hormone replacement for the somatopause? |journal=Hormone Research |volume=53 |issue=Suppl 3 |pages=37–41 |year=2000 |pmid=10971102 |doi=10.1159/000023531}}</ref> However, it is also said to have potentially dangerous side-effects when used in injectable form, if proper protocols are not followed. It is not approved for use in healthy aging patients, though many have been using it for this reason for decades now. That restriction is sidestepped by means of a diagnosis of some injury, organic condition, or adult growth hormone deficiency<ref name="BusWeek">[http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/06_12/b3976001.htm "Selling The Promise Of Youth"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100104094003/http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/06_12/b3976001.htm |date=January 4, 2010 }} cover story ''[[Business Week]] March 20, 2006</ref> which supposedly has resulted in reduced secretion of the hormone.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://health-fit-blog.blogspot.com.ng/2015/11/best-routine-for-personal-skin-care.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304231729/http://health-fit-blog.blogspot.com.ng/2015/11/best-routine-for-personal-skin-care.html |archivedate=2018-03-04 |df= }} "Aging: Disease or Business Opportunity?"] article by [[Duff Wilson]] in ''[[The New York Times]] April 15, 2007</ref>
===Menopausal hormone drugs=== Administration of [[estrogen]] and other hormones such as [[progestin]] were popularized by the 1966 book ''Feminine Forever'' by Robert A. Wilson.<ref>Robert A. Wilson, ''Feminine Forever'', M. Evans and Company, Inc. (June 15, 1968), hardcover, {{ISBN|0-87131-049-X}} {{ISBN|978-0871310491}}</ref> However, the increase of the use of estrogen was shown to be associated with an increased risk of cancer.<ref name=JickAJPH1980CancerEpidemicCommentary>{{cite journal|author1=H Jick|author2=A M Walker|author3=K J Rothman|title=The epidemic of endometrial cancer: a commentary|journal=American Journal of Public Health|date=March 1980|volume=70|issue=3|pages=264–267|doi=10.2105/AJPH.70.3.264|url=http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/abs/10.2105/AJPH.70.3.264|pmc=1619376}}</ref> Later, in 2002, research into the long-term effects of estrogen on post-menopausal women, the [[Women’s Health Initiative]], produced evidence that there were serious side effects.<ref name=WHIPostmenopausalHormoneTrialResults>{{cite web|title=Findings from the WHI Postmenopausal Hormone Therapy Trials|url=http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/whi/|website=Women's Health Initiative|publisher=National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160617000903/http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/whi/|archivedate=2016-06-17|df=}}</ref> Physicians who prescribe the hormones now prescribe low doses of the drugs. Research into the long-term effects of hormone replacement therapy is continuing, with a 2017 [[Cochrane review|Cochrane]] [[systematic review]] concluding that long-term use may decrease the risk of [[Bone fracture|bone fractures]] or [[postmenopausal osteoporosis]], but increase the risk of [[stroke]], [[Myocardial infarction|heart attacks]], [[endometrial cancer]], and [[breast cancer]].<ref name=Marjoribanks2017>{{Cite journal|last=Marjoribanks|first=Jane|last2=Farquhar|first2=Cindy|last3=Roberts|first3=Helen|last4=Lethaby|first4=Anne|last5=Lee|first5=Jasmine|date=2017|title=Long-term hormone therapy for perimenopausal and postmenopausal women|url=|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|volume=1|pages=CD004143|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004143.pub5|issn=1469-493X|pmid=28093732|via=}}</ref> Hormone therapy is generally only recommended for postmenopausal women who are at a high risk of osteoporosis when non-hormonal treatments are not suitable.<ref name=Marjoribanks2017 /> Hormone therapy is not suitable or advised for treating cardiovascular disease, dementia, or for preventing cognitive decline in postmenopausal women.<ref name=Marjoribanks2017 /> The risks of long-term hormonal therapy for women under 50 years of age have not been determined.<ref name="Marjoribanks2017" />
==Scientific approaches== [[Gerontology#Biogerontology|Biogerontology]] is a scientific discipline which has the same area of interest but, as a branch of [[gerontology]], takes a more conservative approach.<ref>"Anti-aging science: The emergence, maintenance, and enhancement of a discipline" article by Jennifer R. Fishman, Robert H. Binstock, and Marcie A. Lambrix in ''Journal of Aging Studies'' Volume 22, Issue 4, December 2008, Pages 295-303 {{doi|10.1016/j.jaging.2008.05.010}}</ref>
==Mass movement== A substantial fraction of older people, taking their cue from [[alternative medicine]], purchase and use [[herbal supplement]]s and other products which promise relief from the incidents and dangers of aging. Some products are not effective while others hold promise.<!--<ref>http://bit.ly/1N88Sv5</ref>--><ref>[http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d011129.pdf 'Health Products for Seniors:] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106233742/http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d011129.pdf |date=2010-01-06 }} "Anti-Aging" Products Pose Danger for Physical and Economic Harm' report by the [[General Accounting Office|GAO]] September, 2001</ref>
== Reception == There are at least two opposite views on the prospects of anti-aging research and development. One group states that there is a great deal of over-heated rhetoric in use with respect to [[life extension]] with over-optimistic projections on the part of its advocates. They also claim that there is little evidence that any significant breakthrough has been made, or is on the horizon.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Turner | first1 = Leigh | authorlink = Leigh Turner | year = 2004 | title = Biotechnology, bioethics and anti-aging interventions | url = | journal = [[Trends in Biotechnology]] | volume = 22 | issue = 5| pages = 219–221 | doi = 10.1016/j.tibtech.2004.03.008 | pmid = 15109806 }}</ref> Some state that, this is largely due to a current lack of funding or interest in the issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://positivefuturist.com/archive/368.html |accessdate=May 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318122344/http://positivefuturist.com/archive/368.html |archivedate=March 18, 2013 }}</ref> A study of the common supplements and hormone treatments used published in 2006 in the ''Cleveland Clinic Journal of Medicine'' showed that none of them are effective with respect to extending life.<ref> {{Cite journal | issn = 0891-1150 | volume = 73 | issue = 12 | pages = 1049–1056, 1058 | last = Kamel | first = Nabil S |author2=Julie Gammack |author3=Oscar Cepeda |author4=Joseph H Flaherty | title = Antioxidants and hormones as antiaging therapies: high hopes, disappointing results | journal = Cleveland Clinic Journal of Medicine | year = 2006 | doi = 10.3949/ccjm.73.12.1049 | pmid = 17190308 }}</ref> Another group notices that recent scientific successes in rejuvenation and extending the lifespan of model animals (mice 2.5 times, yeast and nematodes 10 times)<ref name=AgingResearchOpenLetter>{{cite web|title=Scientists' Open Letter on Aging Research |url=http://www.imminst.org/cureaging/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429170735/http://www.imminst.org/cureaging/ |archivedate=2015-04-29 }}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=July 2015}} and discovery of variety of species (including humans of advanced ages) having [[negligible senescence]] give hope to achieve negligible senescence (cancel ageing) for younger humans, reverse ageing, or at least significantly delay it. Moreover, stopping or delaying aging should be a focus of the modern science and medicine since ageing is the major cause of mortality in the world.<ref name="Lopez 2006">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(06)68770-9 |title=Global and regional burden of disease and risk factors, 2001: Systematic analysis of population health data |year=2006 |last1=Lopez |first1=Alan D |last2=Mathers |first2=Colin D |last3=Ezzati |first3=Majid |last4=Jamison |first4=Dean T |last5=Murray |first5=Christopher JL |journal=The Lancet |volume=367 |issue=9524 |pages=1747–57 |pmid=16731270}}</ref><ref>[http://stanford.edu/group/brunet/background.html Brunet Lab: Molecular Mechanisms of Longevity and Age Related Diseases] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305111818/http://stanford.edu/group/brunet/background.html |date=2016-03-05 }}. Stanford.edu. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
Though some scientists think curing aging is impossible, there are some criticisms of both the time frame life extensionists envision (the first, perhaps somewhat crude, treatments within the next several decades, or at least before the beginning of the 22nd century) and of whether curing aging is even desirable. Common criticisms of the idea of life extension are fears it will cause the world to be more [[Human overpopulation|overpopulated]]; however De Grey counters that by saying that since [[menopause]] would also be delayed, women could wait longer to have children and thus, the rate of growth would actually ''decline'' as a result. Also, the slowly growing population would buy centuries of time to figure out new places to live, such as [[space colonies]].<ref>Gavrilov, Rejuvenation Res. 2010 Apr; 13(2-3): 329–334. "Demographic Consequences of Defeating Aging"</ref>
==See also== {{Refbegin|4}} *[[Death]] *[[Aging]] *[[Brian Hanley (biohacker)]] *[[Senescence]] *[[Negligible senescence]] *[[Biological immortality]] *[[Immortality]] *[[Indefinite lifespan]] *[[Longevity]] *[[Transhumanism]] *[[Extropianism]] *[[Biogerontology]] *[[Life extension]] *[[List of life extension topics]] *[[Index of life extension-related articles]] {{Refend}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Arking R, Butler R, Chiko B, Fossel M, Gavrilov LA, Morley JE, Olshansky SJ, Perls T, Walker RF. Anti-aging teleconference: What is anti-aging medicine? Journal of Anti-Aging Medicine [Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.]. 6(2): 91-106, 2003 * {{cite journal | last1 = De Grey | first1 = Aubrey D. N. | last2 = Gavrilov | first2 = Leonid | last3 = Olshansky | first3 = S. Jay | last4 = Coles | first4 = L. Stephen | last5 = Cutler | first5 = Richard G. | last6 = Fossel | first6 = Michael | last7 = Harman | first7 = S. Mitchell | year = 2002 | title = Antiaging technology and pseudoscience. Letter | url = | journal = Science | volume = 296 | issue = | pages = 656–656 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Gavrilov | first1 = L.A. | year = 2002 | title = Scientific legitimacy of the term "Anti-Aging | url = | journal = Journal of Anti-Aging Medicine | volume = 5 | issue = 2| pages = 239–240 | doi=10.1089/10945450260195685}}

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (3 sources from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox noble|chevalier | name = Antonio Foscarini | father = Nicolò di Alvise | mother = Maria Barbarigo di Antonio | birth_date = 1570 | birth_place = San Polo, Venice | death_date = April 22, 1622 | death_place = Venice, | burial_place = Foscarini Chapel, San Stae, Venice | religion = Protestant sympathiser | occupation = Venetian ambassador to Paris and London }}
'''Antonio Foscarini''' (c. 1570 in Venice – April 22, 1622) belonged to the Venetian nobility and was Venetian ambassador to Paris and later to London . He was the third son of Nicolò di Alvise of the family branch of [[San Polo]] and Maria Barbarigo di Antonio. In 1622 he was sentenced to death for [[high treason]] by the [[Council of Ten]] and executed.
Ten months later, the same council rehabilitated Antonio Foscarini and explicitly informed the European courts of his posthumous exoneration, and the revocation of the guilty verdict and death sentence. Notwithstanding the about turn, mystery still remains as to why an art-loving nobleman was embroiled in a Venetian tale of political intrigue, that involved factional infighting, institutional disputes between Church and State, and religious hostilities over [[Protestantism]] and [[Catholicism]] at the beginning of the [[Thirty Years' War]], that led to the death of an innocent man.
==Background and early political career== Antonio Foscarini had two brothers, Alvise (1560–1617) and Girolamo (1561–1580), and three sisters, Caterina, Agnesina, and Luca Contarini. The Foscarini family lost a substantial part of their wealth, from the [[Ottoman–Venetian War (1570–1573)]] and only the sons received financial support. His father Nicolò died in 1575, and his mother died in 1582, probably by suicide.
Antonio studied in [[Padua]], where he made several lifelong friendships. From 1590 he and his remaining brother Alvise led the household, and in 1592 they agreed to share the considerable fortune of about 70,000 ducats that remained. The family property included estates in [[Padua]], [[Mestrino]], [[Verona]] and [[Venice]], including the family home in [[San Polo]]. In 1595 Foscarini gained a seat in the [[Great Council of Venice|Grand Council]] and in September 1597 was elected to the 'Savio agli Ordini', - the lowest level in the council of ministers the 'Collegio' - where he was witness to the factional infighting between 'conservatives' and 'innovators', the two opposing groups of the nobility. He became a supporter of the 'innovator' [[Paolo Sarpi]].
==Diplomatic career== Foscarini began his political career as an envoy to the court of [[Henry IV of France]] in 1601 and was present at the king's marriage to [[Maria de Medici]]. On May 26, 1607 he was appointed as ambassador to France but did not assume the role until February the next year. In July 1610 he was made ambassador to England, but here too he delayed taking up the position until May 4 of the following year.
These delays in taking up his two appointments formed part of the accusations against him during his two trials, but it was found that he otherwise behaved fittingly. Accusations that he dressed poorly and was stingy were not trivial matters in the estates society. His opposition to the Pope and the [[Jesuit]] order was no secret.
==First Arrest== In February 1615 his secretary, [[Giulio Muscorno]], denounced Foscarini before the [[Council of Ten]], accusing him of selling state secrets to Spain. When Muscorno returned to Venice in March, his replacement, [[Giovanni Rizzardo]], was requested to secretly gather evidence against Foscarini. Foscarini was arrested on his arrival in Venice in December. Three years later he was released without charge and formally absolved on July 30, 1618. In London between January 1616 and June 1617 his successor as ambassador to England, [[Gregorio Barbarigo]], and his secretary Lionello, had searched in vain for evidence against him. In 1620 Foscarini was elected to the senate.<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/cal-state-papers/venice/vol14 Rizzardo's letters to the Inquisitors of State in Vols. XIII and XIV of Calendar & Appendix latter vol.]</ref>
==The Countess of Arundel and the Second Arrest== In 1621, [[Alethea Howard, Countess of Arundel]], reached Venice. She was the granddaughter of [[Bess of Hardwick|Elizabeth of Hardwick]], a goddaughter of [[Queen Elizabeth I]], and wife of [[Thomas Howard, 21st Earl of Arundel]], a leading person at the court of [[King James I]] of England. Foscarini was a friend of the art-loving couple from London and visited the pair at the Palazzo Mocenigo on the [[Grand Canal (Venice)|Grand Canal]] where they were staying.
On April 8, 1622 Foscarini was arrested leaving the Senate. The Council of Ten accused him of meeting with ministers of foreign powers, both in Venice and abroad, and of betraying in words and in writing the most intimate secrets of the Republic. Foscarini was accused of disclosing state secrets to the secretary of Emperor Ferdinand II and to the nuncio of the Pope at the Arundel residence. The agents of the State Inquisition, Domenico and Girolomo Vano were the key witnesses. These, in turn, had received their information from Gian Battista, the servant of the Spanish Ambassador.
Sir [[Henry Wotton]], England's ambassador to Venice, wrote to Arundel that the Senate would declare her an 'unwanted person' and advised her to leave the city immediately. Instead, she hurried to Wotton and requested an audience with [[Doge]] [[Antonio Priuli (doge of Venice)|Antonio Priuli]].<ref>Thomas Duffus Hardy, 'Report', in Report to the Master of the Rolls On Documents in the Archives of Venice (London, 1866), pp. 3-41.[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/no-series/master-of-rolls-report/pp3-41]</ref> She threatened the ambassador, whom she suspected of being involved in the action of the Council of Ten to call for her removal. In fact, she was not only admitted to the Doge, but he assured her that no one wanted to banish her, and promised to restore the honor of Foscarini by writing to London. Six months later she left Venice, bestowed with gifts from the Doge.<ref>Thomas Duffus Hardy, 'Appendix: F. Papers Relating to the Countess of Arundel', in Report to the Master of the Rolls On Documents in the Archives of Venice (London, 1866), pp. 76-84. [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/no-series/master-of-rolls-report/pp76-84]</ref>
==The Trial== The account of the advocate Andrea Querini:<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/cal-state-papers/venice/vol17/pp546-557 Case of the Cavalier Foscarini, by the Advocate Andrea Querini.734.]</ref> The case against Foscarini was preceded by about twelve processes of small consequence that began with letters from England in 1605 written to the Supreme Tribunal by his secretary Giulio Muscorno. Foscarini was said to have incurred the hatred of the King and Court by imprudent discourse to the detriment of public affairs. He wrote to defend himself and Muscorno replied that he went in danger of his life from the ambassador. Subsequently, Foscarini was accused of corresponding with foreigners, and the greater part of the process turned upon this, but in the absence of real proof, only a caution was issued. In 1622, informers declared to the tribunal to have repeatedly seen Foscarini talking with the Spanish ambassador under a certain 'sottoportico in Canareggio'. When questioned Foscarini did not deny the place or the hour but the person and the fact. A presumption of his guilt being established, he was condemned. [[Giovan Battista Nani]] describes these events in his ''Historia della Republica Veneta,''<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/historiadellarep00nani Historia della Republica Veneta, book five]</ref> published in the latter half of the century, but his account contains inaccuracies, as Foscarini's arrival in England was after the beginning of May, 1611 and Muscorno's letters were sent in 1613.
Despite the assurances of the Doge given earlier to the Countess Arundel, Foscarini was convicted on April 22. He was strangled in jail and his body was, in the manner usual for those convicted of [[high treason]], hung head down between the pillars in the [[Piazzetta]]. Before being so hung, his body had been dragged along the ground, from morning to dusk by one leg.
==Rehabilitation== Meanwhile, one of the inquisitors was suspicious and had interrogated the Spanish servant further, whereby he confessed to not having seen Foscarini in the Spanish ambassador's house. Girolamo, who had received a salary on May 23 for services not mentioned, and Domenico Vano, were both summoned and interviewed in August. They confessed to a conspiracy to discredit Foscarini, but the redacted court records reveal no motive, nor who may have been behind the conspiracy.
The Vano pair were convicted but before they were executed, the Foscarini nephews, Nicolò and Girolamo Foscarini, had petitioned the Council of Ten for further interrogation to reveal any co-conspirators, but this was declined. The English ambassador suspected this suggested either the statements of the convicted were of no value, or there were reasons of state.[1]
On 16 January 1623, ten months after the Council of Ten had convicted Antonio Foscarini of high treason, he was exonerated of all charges by the same council.[2]
The prosecutors were brought before the State Inquisition and the Council of Ten. The latter publicly acknowledged their error. Copies of the corresponding letters were sent to the Foscarini family and to all the estates in Europe.
Foscarini was exhumed and reburied with a state funeral. A statue was erected in the Foscarini Chapel in the church of [[San Stae]] on the Grand Canal. The Doge [[Marco Foscarini]] (1762-1763), a descendant of Antonio's brother Alvise, praised the Council of Ten for revoking its earlier judgment.
==Background== Antonio Foscarini was a follower of the so-called 'Giovani', a group in the Venetian nobility with sympathy for the Protestant rulers who supported them during the Thirty Years' War. When Foscarini was an ambassador to London, he made friends with Sir Henry Wotton<ref>Smith, Logan Pearsall, The Life and Letters of Sir HenryWotton, Vol. II, (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1907), pp. 163-4.[https://archive.org/stream/lifelettersofsir02smit]</ref> (later to become British ambassador to Venice) and formed a formal alliance with England.
In addition, Venice had drawn the consequences in a lawsuit since 1605 and banished [[Theatines]], [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|Capuchin]]s and [[Jesuits]] from its dominion. In return, the Pope had imposed on 17 April 1606, the [[Venetian Interdict|Interdict on Venice]]. When this was abolished in 1607, the Jesuits were not allowed to return. The Venetian Republic challenged Papal authority and mistrusted the Jesuit order, with its strong Spanish ties. Venice resented Spanish power and her league with Florence, Milan and Naples. Savoy was the only other Italian state not subject to Spanish supremacy. [[Paolo Sarpi]] led an anti-papal group, opposing temporal privileges of the Pope.
The conflict between the 'Giovani' (the boys), and their opponents, 'Il Vecchi', (the ancients), also [[Papists]] was an important background to Foscarini's conviction. Until the death of Doge [[Leonardo Donato]] (1606-1612), 'the boys' dominated, but until 1631 they had intermittent influence.
The [[Habsburgs]], leaders of the [[Counter-Reformation]] forces, involved Venice in a war under the leadership of [[Ferdinand II, Archduke of Inner Austria|Archduke Ferdinand]], who in 1617 entered into the [[Treaty of Madrid (1617)|Treaty of Madrid]]. [[The Spanish Viceroy]] in Naples, the [[Duke of Osuna]], refused to surrender. While his ships attacked Venetian merchants in the [[Adriatic]], rumors circulated in Venice that the Spanish embassy was forming a core of supporters against the city. Many Venetians gathered before the embassy and the courts condemned more than a hundred men for treason. Three Spaniards were executed immediately.
The coup attempt sparked strong anti-Spanish sentiment in Venice even among pro-papal groups. Significantly Giambattista Bragadino, a member of the impoverished nobility, the so-called [[Barnabotti]], having confessed to contact with the Spanish ambassador, was also executed. With the crowd surrounding the embassy, the Spanish Ambassador, the Marquess of Bedmar, decided to leave the city.
The denunciation of Antonio Foscarini by his secretary Giulio Muscarno, and subsequent arrest in 1615 had come in the midst of this crisis. He was eventually acquitted of selling information to the Spaniards but only after three years in detention. Muscarno was stripped of his office and sentenced to two years in prison.
Foscarini's second denunciation in 1622 may have arisen from first indictment, his Protestant sympathies, the antipathy of his secretary Muscarno, or the general fear of Spain's intrigue, but which of these, is impossible to ascertain.
Since 1310 the Council of the Ten dealt with cases of high treason. For both important dates, the day of the conviction (22 April 1622) and day of the rehabilitation (16 January 1623), the composition of the Council of the Ten is known. This Council of Ten, which had six councilors in addition to the Doge, consisted of ten senators, although a total of 17 men participated at the meetings. From their circle these determined three administrators of state, or 'Avogadori di Commun', one of whom would be a council of the Doge, the other two were elected by the senators. The three 'Avogadori' retained numerous informers, informants and henchmen, paid for from their own cash funds, and kept no records. The senate election to the Council were for one year terms, but the term commencement dates varied, so the Council composition changed monthly, but gradually.
Doge Antonio Priuli, Alvise Contarini, Francesco Molin and Battista Nani were all possible Papists, but the number of Papist members of the Council in 1622 cannot be determined.
In 1623, the presidents, ([[Capi (Venice)|Capi]]), were Anzolo da Mosto, Marcantonio Mocenigo and [[Nicolò Contarini]]. According to Sarpi, Contarini was one of the brains of the Giovani, and Mocenigo supported them. Only Battista Nani, the third to sign the rehabilitation, was not one of them. Nani had been in the Council of Ten at the time of the sentencing of 1622, but had been one of four who voted for imprisonment and not execution.
Vincenzo Dandolo, like Nani, was present at both sessions. He was an old acquaintance of Contarini and probably owed him his Senate seat, and they had fought together in the Gradisca War 1615-1617. He had sought the harshest condemnation, and in 1623, voted for rehabilitation.
Whether the 'Giovani' and 'Papalisti' rivalry was behind the execution and rehabilitation is unknown. In 1622 Foscarini was so discredited that Paolo Sarpi had publicly declined the 100 [[ducats]] from the legacy of Foscarini, provided in his Will, on the eve of the execution for Sarpi's prayers. Sarpi may have rejected the inheritance in the belief of his guilt, or he may have feared for himself and his group.
==literature== *Jonathan Walker: Antonio Foscarini in the City of Crossed Destinies, in: Rethinking History, Vol. 5, No. 2, 2001, pp. 305–334. *Murray Brown: The Myth of Antonio Foscarini's Exoneration, in: Renaissance and Reformation / Renaissance et Reforms. Société Canadienne d'Etudes de la Renaissance 25/3 (2001) 25-42. *Ida von Reinsberg-Düringsfeld : Antonio Foscarini, 4 vols, Stuttgart 1850.
