{{moresources|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} {{For|the 1977 film|Guruvayur Kesavan (film)}}
[[File:Guruvayoor Kesavan Statue.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Guruvayoor Kesavan's Statue at [[Guruvayur]].]]
'''Gajarajan Guruvayur Keshavan''' (died 2 December 1976)<ref name=Kesavan>{{Cite web|url=http://guruvayurdevaswom.nic.in/kesavan.html|title=Gajarajan Kesavan|last=|first=|date=|website=Guruvayur Devaswom|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180310031648/http://guruvayurdevaswom.nic.in/kesavan.html|archive-date=2018-03-10|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-10}}</ref><ref name=Hindu>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2005/12/11/stories/2005121102861000.htm|title='Guruvayur Kesavan' remembered|last=|first=|date=2005-12-11|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-03-10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> is perhaps the most famous and celebrated temple [[Elephants in Kerala culture|elephant in Kerala]], India. Keshavan was donated to the [[Guruvayur]] [[Hindu]] temple by the royal family of [[Nilambur]] on 4 January 1922 .<ref name=Hindu/> It is a common Hindu custom in Kerala to capture elephants either as calves or young adults from the wild and to donate them to the deity of the temple as an offering. Guruvayur temple has in excess of 50 elephants.
Standing over 3.4 meters tall, Keshavan was known for his devout behavior. Keshavan died on 2 December 1976, aged 72, which happened to be [[Guruvayur Ekadasi]], considered a very auspicious day.<ref name=Kesavan/><ref name=Hindu/> He fasted for the entire day and dropped down facing the direction of the temple with his trunk raised as a mark of prostration. The anniversary of his death is still celebrated in Guruvauyur. Many elephants line up before the statue and the chief elephant garlands it. Keshavan was conferred the unique title "Gajarajan" (Elephant King), by the Guruvayoor [[Devaswom]].
The Guruvayoor Devaswom erected a life-size statue of Keshavan in its precincts as tribute to the services he rendered to the presiding deity of the temple. Its tusks, along with a majestic portrait of the elephant, can be still seen adorning the entrance to the main temple enclosure. Its life is the subject of the 1977 [[Malayalam]] feature film ''[[Guruvayur Kesavan (film)|Guruvayur Kesavan]]'', released the year after his death. The film was directed by [[Bharathan]], starring [[M. G. Soman]], [[Adoor Bhasi]], [[Sankaradi]], [[Bahadoor]], [[Jayabharathi]], [[Vennira Aadai Nirmala]] (ushakumari), [[Veeran]], [[Oduvil Unnikrishnan]], junior sheela, M S Nambudiri, [[N Govindankutty]], [[Paravoor Bharathan]] and [[Manavalan Joseph]] zoomed by [[Ashok Kumar (cinematographer)]]. The story of Guruvayoor Kesavan was later portrayed in a television serial on [[Surya TV]], (2009—2010)
==See also== * [[Cultural depictions of elephants]] * [[Elephants in Kerala culture]] * [[Guruvayur Temple]] * [[List of individual elephants]] * [[Kolakolli]], a notorious rogue elephant
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}
==References== {{commonscat}} *[http://www.guruvayurdevaswom.org/kesavan.shtml Guruvayoor Devaswom Webpage] *[http://imdb.com/title/tt0155734/ IMDB]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Bed bug]] (link changed to [[Bed bug (insect)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{Infobox disease | Name = Infestation | Image = | Caption = | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|B|65||b|65}}-{{ICD10|B|88|9|b|85}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|120}}-{{ICD9|129}}, {{ICD9|132}}-{{ICD9|134}} | ICDO = | OMIM = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicineSubj = | eMedicineTopic = | MeshID = }}
'''Infestation''' is the state of being invaded or overrun by [[pest (organism)|pests]] or [[parasite]]s.<ref>{{DorlandsDict|four/000053484|infestation}}</ref> It can also refer to the actual organisms living on or within a [[Host (biology)|host]].<ref name="urlInfestation - Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary">{{cite web |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/infestation |title=Infestation - Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary |format= |work= |accessdate=}}</ref>
== Terminology == In general, the term "infestation" refers to [[parasitic disease]]s caused by [[animal]]s such as [[arthropod]]s (i.e. [[mite]]s, [[tick]]s, and [[louse|lice]]) and [[worm]]s, but excluding conditions caused by [[protozoan infection|protozoa]], [[fungi]], [[bacterial infection|bacteria]], and [[virus]]es,<ref name="SchoolKomaroff2004">{{cite book|author1=Harvard Medical School|author2=[[Anthony L. Komaroff]]|title=Harvard Medical School Family Health Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1QE1C5cyI4YC&pg=PT889|accessdate=24 April 2010|date=28 December 2004|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-0-684-86373-3|pages=889–}}</ref> which are called [[infection]]s.
== External and internal == Infestations can be classified as either external or internal with regards to the parasites' location in relation to the host.
External or [[ectoparasitic infestation]] is a condition in which organisms live primarily on the surface of the host (though [[porocephaliasis]] can penetrate viscerally) and includes those involving mites, [[tick infestation|ticks]], [[head-louse infestation|head lice]] and [[Bed bug (insect)|bed bugs]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bed Bug Information|url=http://www.epa.gov/bedbugs/}}</ref>
An internal (or [[endoparasite|endoparasitic]]) infestation is a condition in which organisms live within the host and includes those involving worms (though [[swimmer's itch]] stays near the surface).
Medically, the term "infestation" is often reserved only for external ectoparasitic infestations<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/guide/bedbugs-infestation|title=Bedbugs|publisher= Skin Problems & Treatments Health Center|accessdate=2013-11-20}}</ref> while the term ''[[infection]]'' refers to internal endoparasitic conditions.<ref name="ShapiroShapiro2005">{{cite book |author1=Leland S. Shapiro|author2=Leland Shapiro|title=Pathology and parasitology for veterinary technicians |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=FB0KmsI_1jAC&pg=PA111 111-] |year=2005 |publisher=Cengage Learning |isbn=978-1-4018-3745-7 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Helminthiases}} {{Arthropod infestations}}

revision.text:
{{short description|Hypothesis that during the course of chordate evolution, the structures along the dorsoventral axis have taken on an orientation opposite that of the ancestral form}} In [[evolutionary developmental biology]], '''inversion''' refers to the hypothesis that during the course of animal evolution, the structures along the [[anatomical terms of location|dorsoventral]] (DV) axis have taken on an orientation opposite that of the ancestral form.
Inversion was first noted in 1822 by the French zoologist [[Étienne Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire]], when he dissected a [[crayfish]] (an [[arthropod]]) and compared it with the [[vertebrate]] [[body plan]]. The idea was heavily criticised, but periodically resurfaced, and is now supported by some molecular embryologists.
==History==
As early as 1822, the French zoologist [[Étienne Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire]] noted that the organization of [[Dorsal (anatomy)|dorsal]] and [[anatomical terms of location|ventral]] structures in [[arthropod]]s is opposite that of [[mammal]]s. Five decades later, in light of [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]]'s theory of "descent with modification", German zoologist [[Anton Dohrn]] proposed that these groups arose from a [[common descent|common ancestor]] which possessed a body plan similar to that of modern [[annelid]]s with a [[ventral nerve cord]] and dorsal heart.<ref name=Gerhart2000>{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.97.9.4445 |author=Gerhart, J. |title=Inversion of the chordate body axis: Are there alternatives? |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA |volume=97 |pages=4445–8 |year=2000 |pmid=10781041 |issue=9 |pmc=34319|bibcode=2000PNAS...97.4445G }}</ref> Whereas this arrangement is retained in [[arthropod]]s and other [[protostome]]s, in [[chordate]] [[deuterostome]]s, the [[dorsal nerve cord|nerve cord]] is located dorsally and the heart ventrally. The inversion hypothesis was met with scornful criticism each time it was proposed, and has periodically resurfaced and been rejected.<ref name=Gerhart2000 /> However, some modern molecular embryologists suggest that recent findings support the idea of inversion.
== Evidence for inversion ==
[[File:DV-axis-inversion.png|thumb|270px|Generalized protostome and chordate body plans illustrating the opposite orientation of dorsoventral structures. Concomitant with the change in orientation of these structures is the inversion of domains of expression of TGF-β signals (''dpp''/BMPs) and their inhibitors (''sog''/Chordin).]] [[File:Ptychodera flava in New Caledonia, from Encyclopaedia Britannica (1911).png|thumb|left|80px|''[[Balanoglossus]]'', an example of a ''Hemichordata'', represents an "evolutionary link" between invertebrates and vertebrates.]]
In addition to the simple observation that the dorsoventral axes of protostomes and chordates appear to be inverted with respect to each other, [[molecular biology]] provides some support for the inversion hypothesis. The most notable piece of evidence comes from analysis of the [[gene]]s involved in establishing the DV axis in these two groups.<ref name=DeRobertis>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/380037a0 |vauthors=De Robertis EM, Sasai Y|title=A common plan for dorsoventral patterning in Bilateria |journal=Nature |volume=380 |pages=37–40 |year=1996 |pmid=8598900 |issue=6569|bibcode=1996Natur.380...37D }}</ref> In the fruit fly ''[[Drosophila melanogaster]]'', as well as in other protostomes, the β-type transforming growth factor ([[Transforming growth factor beta|TGF-β]]) family member ''[[decapentaplegic]]'' (''dpp'') is expressed dorsally and is thought to suppress neural fate. On the ventral side of the embryo, a ''dpp'' inhibitor, ''short gastrulation'' (''sog''), is expressed, thus allowing nervous tissue to form ventrally. In chordates, the ''dpp'' [[Homology (biology)#Homology of sequences in genetics|homolog]] [[Bone morphogenetic protein 4|BMP-4]] is expressed in the prospective ventral (non-neural) part of the embryo while several ''sog''-like BMP inhibitors ([[Chordin]], [[Noggin (protein)|Noggin]], [[Follistatin]]) are expressed dorsally.<ref name=Gerhart2000 />
Other [[Pattern formation#Biology|patterning]] genes also show conserved domains of expression. The neural patterning genes ''vnd'', ''ind'', ''msh'', and ''[[netrin]]'' are expressed in the [[Drosophila melanogaster|''Drosophila'']] ventral nerve cells and midline mesectoderm. The chordate [[Homology (biology)#Homology of sequences in genetics|homologs]] of these genes, [[NK2 homeobox 1|NK2]], Gsh1/2, Msx1/3, and [[Netrin]], are expressed in the dorsal [[neural tube]]. Furthermore, the [[NKX2-5|tinman/Nkx2-5]] gene is expressed very early in cells that will become the [[heart]] in both [[Drosophila melanogaster|''Drosophila'']] (dorsally) and chordates (ventrally).<ref name=Gerhart2000 />
Additional support comes from work on the development of the [[polychaete]] [[annelid]] ''[[Platynereis dumerilii]]'', another protostome. Even more so than ''Drosophila'', its pattern of central-nervous-system development is strikingly similar to that of vertebrates, but inverted.<ref name=Denes2007>{{cite journal | doi=10.1016/j.cell.2007.02.040 |author1=Alexandru S. Denes |author2=Gáspár Jékely |author3=Patrick R.H. Steinmetz |author4=Florian Raible |author5=Heidi Snyman |author6=Benjamin Prud'homme |author7=David E.K. Ferrier |author8=Guillaume Balavoine |author9=Detlev Arendt | title=Molecular Architecture of Annelid Nerve Cord Supports Common Origin of Nervous System Centralization in Bilateria | journal=Cell | volume=129 | issue=2 | pages=277–288 | year=2007 | pmid=17448990 }}</ref> There is also evidence from left-right asymmetry. Vertebrates have a highly conserved Nodal signaling pathway that acts on the left side of the body, determining left-right asymmetries of internal organs. [[Sea urchin]]s have the same signaling pathway, but it acts on the right side of the body.<ref name=Duboc2005>{{cite journal | doi=10.1016/j.devcel.2005.05.008 |author1=Véronique Duboc |author2=Eric Röttinger |author3=François Lapraz |author4=Lydia Besnardeau |author5=Thierry Lepage | title=Left-Right Asymmetry in the Sea Urchin Embryo Is Regulated by Nodal Signaling on the Right Side | journal=Developmental Cell | volume=9 | issue=1 | pages=147–158 | year=2005 | pmid=15992548 }}</ref> It was even shown that an opposing right-sided signal for regulating left-right asymmetry in vertebrates, i.e. BMP signaling pathway, is activated on the left side of the sea urchin larva,<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Luo YJ, Su YH |title=Opposing Nodal and BMP Signals Regulate Left–Right Asymmetry in the Sea Urchin Larva|journal=PLoS Biology|year=2012|volume=10|issue=10|pages=e1001402|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.1001402| pmid=23055827 |pmc=3467216}}</ref> suggesting an axial inversion during evolution from basal deuterostome to chordate such like amphioxus. Because in amphioxus, Nodal signaling pathway is on the left side of the embryo, which is the same situation as vertebrates.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Yu JK, Holland LZ, Holland ND |title=An amphioxus nodal gene (AmphiNodal) with early symmetrical expression in the organizer and mesoderm and later asymmetrical expression associated with left-right axis formation.|journal=Evolution & Development|year=2002|volume=4|issue=6|pages=418–25|pmid=12492142|doi=10.1046/j.1525-142x.2002.02030.x}}</ref> Sea urchins, like other echinoderms, have radially-symmetric adults, but bilaterally-symmetric larvae. Since sea urchins are deuterostomes, this suggests that the ancestral deuterostome shared its orientation with protostomes, and that dorsoventral inversion originated in some ancestral chordate.
There is evidence that invertebrate chordates are also inverted. [[Ascidian]] larvae have a dorsal mouth, as one would expect from inversion.<ref name=Lacalli2006>{{cite journal | doi=10.7150/ijbs.2.104 | author=Thurston C. Lacalli | title=Prospective protochordate homologs of vertebrate midbrain and MHB, with some thoughts on MHB origins | journal=International Journal of Biological Sciences | volume=2 | issue=3 | pages=104–109 | year=2006 | pmid=16763669 | pmc=1458436 }}</ref> The [[amphioxus]] has an odd feature: its mouth appears on the left side and migrates to the ventral side.<ref name=Yasui2008>{{cite journal | doi=10.2108/zsj.25.1012 |author1=Kinya Yasui |author2=Takao Kaji | title=The Lancelet and Ammocoete Mouths | journal=Zoological Science | volume=25 | issue=10 | pages=1012–1019 | year=2008 | pmid=19267637 | url=http://home.hiroshima-u.ac.jp/rinkai/1.pdf }}</ref> Biologist Thurston Lacalli speculates that this may be a recapitulation of the migration of the mouth from the dorsal to the ventral side in a protochordate.<ref name=Lacalli2009>{{cite journal | doi=10.1111/j.1463-6395.2008.00384.x | author=Thurston C. Lacalli | title=The emergence of the chordate body plan: some puzzles and problems | journal=Acta Zoologica | volume=91 | issue=1 | pages=4–10 | year=2009 }}</ref>
=== Hemichordates: an intermediate body plan? ===
Some biologists have proposed that the [[Hemichordata|Hemichordates]] (specifically the [[Acorn worm|Enteropneusta]]) may represent an intermediate body plan in the evolution of the "inverted" state of the chordates.<ref name=Nubler1999>{{cite journal |doi=10.1046/j.1439-0469.1999.372106.x |vauthors=Nübler-Jung K, Arendt D|title=Dorsoventral axis inversion: Enteropneust anatomy links invertebrates to chordates turned upside down |journal=J Zool Syst Evol Research |volume=37 |pages=93–100 |year=1999 |issue=2}}</ref> Though they are considered deuterostomes, the dorsoventral axis of hemichordates retains features of both protostomes and chordates. For example, enteropneusts have an [[ectoderm]]ally-derived dorsal nerve cord in the collar region which has been proposed to be homologous to the chordate neural tube. However, they also have a ventral nerve cord and a dorsal contractile vessel similar to protostomes.<ref name=Nubler1999 /> Furthermore, the relative positions other "intermediate" structures in hemichordates, such as the hepatic organs and ventral pygochord, which has been proposed to be homologous to the chordate-defining [[notochord]],<ref>{{cite journal |author=Cameron CB |title=A phylogeny of the hemichordates based on morphological characters |journal=Can J Zool |volume=83 |pages=196–215 |year=2005 |doi=10.1139/Z04-190}}</ref> are retained but inverted. Nübler-Jung and Arendt argue that the principal innovation in the chordate lineage was the obliteration of the mouth on the neural side (as in hemichordates, arthropods, and annelids) and the development of a new mouth on the non-neural ventral side.<ref name=Nubler1999 />
== Alternative hypotheses ==
While the idea of dorsoventral axis inversion appears to be supported by morphological and molecular data, others have proposed alternative plausible hypotheses (reviewed in Gerhart 2000).<ref name=Gerhart2000 /> One assumption of the inversion hypothesis is that the common ancestor of protostomes and chordates already possessed an organized central nervous system located at one pole of the dorsoventral axis. Alternatively, this ancestor may have possessed only a diffuse nerve net or several bundles of nervous tissue with no distinct dorsoventral localization. <ref name=Gerhart2000 /> <ref name=Martin-Duran2017>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nature25030 |vauthors=Martin-Duran JM, Pang K, Børve A, Semmler Lê H, Furu A, Cannon JT, Jondelius U, Hejnol A |title=Convergent evolution of bilaterian nerve cords |journal=Nature |volume=553 |issue=7686 |pages=1–8 |year=2017 |pmid=29236686 |pmc=5756474|bibcode=2018Natur.553...45M }}</ref> This would mean that the apparent inversion was simply a result of concentration of the central nervous system at opposite poles independently in the lineages leading to protostomes and chordates. Lacalli (1996) suggested a scenario in which the ancestor had a single opening to the digestive system, and that the neural and non-neural mouths arose independently in protostomes and chordates, respectively.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/bies.950180313 |author=Lacalli T |title=Dorsoventral axis inversion: a phylogenetic perspective |journal=BioEssays |volume=18 |pages=251–4 |year=1996 |issue=3}}</ref> By this hypothesis, there is no need for inversion.
Martindale and Henry propose a [[ctenophora|ctenophore]]-like ancestor with a concentrated nerve cord and two anal pores on opposite sides of the animal in addition to a terminal gut opening.<ref name=Gerhart2000 /><ref name=Martindale>{{cite journal |vauthors=Martindale MQ, Henry JQ|title=The development of radial and biradial symmetry: The evolution of bilaterality |journal=Am. Zool. |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages=672–84 |year=1998 |doi=10.1093/icb/38.4.672}}</ref> If one of these pores became the mouth in protostomes and the other became the mouth in deuterostomes, this would also preclude inversion. Another alternative, proposed by von Salvini-Plawen, states that the ancestor had a two-part nervous system - one part concentrated, the other diffuse. The nervous systems of protostome and deuterostome descendants of this ancestor may have arisen independently from these two distinct parts.<ref name=Gerhart2000 /><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1439-0469.1998.tb00832.x |author=von Salvini-Plawen L |title=The urochordate larva and archichordate organization: chordate origin and anagenesis revisited |journal=J. Zool. Syst. Evol. Res. |volume=36 |pages=129–45 |year=1998 |issue=3}}</ref>
'''[[Contralateral brain|Axial twist]]''' theories propose that not the whole body, but only the anterior region of the head is inverted.<ref name="Kinsbourne13">{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/a0033662 |pmid=24040928 |title=Somatic twist: A model for the evolution of decussation |journal=Neuropsychology |volume=27 |issue=5 |pages=511–5 |year=2013 |last1=Kinsbourne |first1=Marcel }}</ref><ref name="Lussanet12">{{cite journal |doi=10.1163/157075611X617102 |arxiv=1003.1872 |title=An ancestral axial twist explains the contralateral forebrain and the optic chiasm in vertebrates |journal=Animal Biology |volume=62 |issue=2 |pages=193–216 |year=2012 |last1=De Lussanet |first1=Marc H.E |last2=Osse |first2=Jan W.M }}</ref> These theories by [[Marcel Kinsbourne|Kinsbourne]]<ref name="Kinsbourne13" /> and de Lussanet & Osse<ref name="Lussanet12" /> also explain the presence of an optic chiasm in vertebrates and the contralateral organization of the [[forebrain]]. One of these theories<ref name="Lussanet12" /> is supported by [[developmental]] evidence and even explains the asymmetric organization of the [[heart]] and [[bowels]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = de Lussanet M. H. E., Osse J. W. M. | year = 2015 | title = Decussation as an axial twist: A comment on Kinsbourne (2013) | url = | journal = Neuropsych | volume = 29 | issue = 5| pages = 713–714 | doi = 10.1037/neu0000163 }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.mindcreators.com/DevelopmentalSim/DorsalVentral.htm An explanation of DV patterning in ''Drosophila''] * [http://scienceblogs.com/pharyngula/2006/01/12/hemichordate-evodevo/ P.Z. Myers on axis inversion and hemichordates] * [http://scienceblogs.com/pharyngula/2007/05/04/we-have-the-brains-of-worms/ P.Z. Myers on axis inversion and annelids: "We have the brains of worms"]
{{evolution}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Congressman |name=José Francisco de Peralta y López del Corral |nationality=[[Costa Rica]]n |order=Deputy of the [[Legislative Assembly of Costa Rica]] |profession=[[Priest]] |image= |birth_date=1783-04-03 |birth_place=[[Cartago, Costa Rica]] |death_date=1844-09-16 |death_place=Cartago |religion=[[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] }}
''' José Francisco de Peralta y López del Corral ''' (April 3, 1786 - September 16, 1844) was a [[Costa Rica]]n [[priest]] and [[politician]]. He was born in [[Cartago, Costa Rica]], the son of [[José María de Peralta y La Vega]] and Ana Benita de Nava López del Corral. Peralta attended the [[University of León (Nicaragua)|University of León]] and was ordained as a pastor in [[León, Nicaragua]] in 1812. He was named a [[parish priest]] for the village [[Olocuilta]], [[El Salvador]].<ref name="Benson">{{cite journal|title=The Central American Delegation to the First Constituent Congress of Mexico, 1822-1823|author=[[Nettie Lee Benson]] and Charles R. Berry|journal=The Hispanic American Historical Review|volume=49|issue=4|date=Nov 1969|pages=697–8, 701|jstor=2511161|publisher=Duke University Press}}</ref>
In 1822, Costa Rica elected Peralta to represent it in the First Constituent Congress of the [[First Mexican Empire|Mexican Empire]], but he did not attend the Congress, because he did not receive instruction from the municipal council of Cost Rican until September, too late to arrive before [[Agustín de Iturbide|Iturbide]] abolished the Congress in October.<ref name="Benson"/> In 1825, he was elected Deputy for Costa Rica to the Congress of the [[Federal Republic of Central America]], a post which he held until 1826, during which he participated in the legislation of several important laws, including the annexation of the [[Partido de Nicoya]] to Costa Rica.
From 1827 to 1828 Peralta was a Deputy for [[Ujarrás]] in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Costa Rica, and in November, 1829, he was elected to represent Costa Rica in the Senate of the [[Federal Republic of Central America]]. From 1832 to 1833 he was the Deputy for [[Santa Cruz de Guanacaste Canton|Santa Cruz, Costa Rica]] in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Costa Rica. Peralta served as President of the Assembly from September 1832 to February 1833 and from July 1833 to September 1833.
In 1835, Peralta participated in the Costa Rican [[civil war]], the ''[[Guerra de la Liga]]'' ({{lang-en|"War of the League"}}) against Head of State [[Braulio Carrillo Colina]]. For this reason, his property was seized by the state and he had to flee in exile.
Peralta had been an enthusiastic admirer of General [[Francisco Morazán Quesada]], who he honored during the general's stay in [[Cartago, Costa Rica]] in 1834. Peralta was one of the most prominent supporters of the government of General Francisco Morazán, who rose to power on 12 April 1842.<ref name="Benson"/> As a result, Peralta was elected Deputy for Cartago to the Constituent Assembly convened by Morazán, which began on 10 July 1842 in [[San José, Costa Rica]]. Peralta was named President of the Assembly.<ref name="Benson"/> Among the legislative projects that he pushed were the creation of the college San Luis Gozaga in Cartago, which would not actually open until 1869.
Peralta died in Cartago on 16 September 1844, after an accident riding a horse. He left an important [[bequest]] for the foundation of a school for the children of Cartago, an institution which retains his name today. In the city a bust in honor of Peralta was unveiled in 1917.
== References == <references />
== Bibliography == * {{cite book|author=Obregón Loría, Rafael|title=El Poder Legislativo en Costa Rica|location=San José|publisher=Editorial Costa Rica|edition=1|year=1966|language=Spanish}} * {{cite book|author=Ortiz de Aragón, Mireya|title=La herencia del prócer|location=Cartago|publisher=Editorial A.G. COVAO|edition=1|year=1997}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Peralta, Jose Francisco}} [[Category:Presidents of the Legislative Assembly of Costa Rica]] [[Category:1786 births]] [[Category:1844 deaths]] [[Category:People from Cartago Province]] [[Category:Deaths by horse-riding accident]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Costa Rica]]

page.title: List of International Space Station spacewalks

revision.text:
[[File:ISSFinalConfigEnd2006.jpg|thumb|250px|An artist's rendering of the fully assembled International Space Station, as it would appear from a spacecraft flying overhead|alt=A computer-generated image of a mechanical object floating above a blue planet exhibiting white clouds all under a black expanse]] [[File:STS-88EVA.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Jerry L. Ross|Jerry Ross]] during one of the first spacewalks that began assembly of the [[International Space Station]]|alt=An astronaut in a white spacesuit with a red, white, and blue flag on the left shoulder in the foreground with a black background]] '''International Space Station spacewalks''' are major events in the building and maintaining of the orbital laboratory.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/station/eva/index.html|title=Space Station Extravehicular Activity|accessdate=October 3, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2008|author=NASA}} [[Extra-vehicular activity|Spacewalks]] are performed to install new components to the [[International Space Station]] (ISS), to re-wire systems, modules, and equipment, and to monitor, install, and retrieve scientific experiments.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/station/eva/construction.html|title=Preparing for Hands-On Construction in Outer Space|accessdate=October 3, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2008|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/station/eva/construction.html|title=A New Generation of Space Robotics|accessdate=October 3, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2008|author=NASA}} Due to the complexity of building a station in [[Outer space|space]], space agencies train astronauts extensively, preparing them to encounter surprises during spacewalks, teaching them how to assemble special tools and equipment, and carefully coordinating every activity during spacewalks. From 1998 to 2005, [[List of International Space Station expeditions|thirty-seven space shuttle missions]] were scheduled to assemble, outfit and begin [[Scientific research on the International Space Station|experiments and research aboard the station]]. The initial spacewalk to begin the [[assembly of the International Space Station]] was held on December 7, 1998, following the launch of the first section of the station, ''[[Zarya]]'', from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome]], Kazakhstan, on November 20, 1998.{{Cite web|title=ISS Zarya|publisher=Encyclopedia Astronautica|url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/isszarya.htm|accessdate=July 14, 2012}} The spacewalk attached the U.S.-built [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'']] node to ''Zarya''.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-88/sts-88-day-05-highlights.html|title=STS-88 Day 5 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=1998|author=NASA}} The longest spacewalk was performed on March 11, 2001, when [[STS-102]] crew members [[Susan J. Helms]] and [[James S. Voss]] conducted a full spacewalk, and then returned to the airlock, but remained in their suits ready to exit the airlock again in case the robotics operations ran into problems. The total time for that spacewalk was eight hours and fifty-six minutes.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-102/sts-102-day-04-highlights.html|title=STS-102 Day 4 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}} As of August 16, 2018, there have been 212 spacewalks devoted to assembly and maintenance of the International Space Station totaling 1327 hours and 17 minutes. As of May 12, 2017, there have been 200 spacewalks totaling 1247 hours and 55 minutes. As of March 2, 2011, a total time of 973 hours and fifty-three minutes has been spent in [[extra-vehicular activity]] (EVA),{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/network/news/space/home/spacecalc/evastats.html|title=ISS EVA Statistics|accessdate=March 6, 2011|publisher=CBS News|date=March 2, 2011|first=William|last=Harwood}} with 127 of these EVAs performed from station [[airlock]]s, totaling 787 hours and twenty-eight minutes in spacewalk time from the station itself. Twenty-eight spacewalks have been performed from a shuttle, ninety-three from the [[Quest Joint Airlock]], thirty-two from the [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]], and two from the transfer compartment at the forward end of the [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']] Service Module.ISS status report 12/23/08 states that sixty-six EVAs have been from ''Quest''. However, all NASA references verify that only sixty-five EVAs have been from ''Quest'', as of the [[Expedition 18]] EVA on March 11, 2009. *denotes spacewalks performed from the [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]] in Russian [[Orlan space suit|Orlan]] suits.
^denotes spacewalks performed from the [[Poisk (ISS module)|''Poisk'' module]] in Russian Orlan suits.
†denotes spacewalks performed from the visiting space shuttle's airlock.
‡denotes the one EVA and one IVA performed from the transfer compartment at the forward end of the [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']] Service Module.
All other spacewalks were performed from the [[Quest Joint Airlock|''Quest'' airlock]].
ISS Expedition spacewalks are separated from shuttle spacewalks by a separator. ==1998–1999== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | scope="col" width="100" | | scope="col" width="100" |

22:10 | December 8, 1998
05:31 | 7 hours, 21 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Connected computer and electrical cables between the [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'']] node, the two mating adapters attached to either end of ''Unity'', and the ''[[Zarya]]'' [[Functional Cargo Block]] (FGB). |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |2. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-88]]

† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jerry L. Ross]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[James H. Newman]] | December 9, 1998
20:33 | December 10, 1998
03:35 | 7 hours, 02 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed two box-like antennas on the outside of the ''Unity'' module that are part of the S-band early communications system.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-88/sts-88-day-07-highlights.html|title=STS-88 Day 7 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=1998|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2 |3. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-88]]
EVA 3
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jerry L. Ross]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[James H. Newman]] | December 12, 1998
20:33 | December 13, 1998
03:32 | 6 hours, 59 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Checked on an insulation cover on a cable connection on the lower [[Pressurized Mating Adapter]] (PMA 2) to make sure it is fully installed, attached EVA tools on the side of ''Unity'''s upper mating adapter (PMA 1) in preparation for future EVAs, and inspected [[Advanced Space Vision System|Orbiter Space Vision System]] targets on ''Unity''.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-88/sts-88-day-08-highlights.html|title=STS-88 Day 8 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=1998|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2 |4. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-96]]

02:56 | May 30, 1999
10:51 | 7 hours, 55 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Transferred and installed two cranes from the shuttle's payload bay to locations on the outside of the station. Installed two new portable foot restraints that will fit both American and Russian space boots, and attached three bags filled with tools and handrails that will be used during future assembly operations.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-96/sts-96-day-04-highlights.html|title=STS-96 Day 4 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=1999|author=NASA}} |} ==2000== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | scope="col" width="100" | | scope="col" width="100" |

† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[James S. Voss]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Jeffrey N. Williams]] | May 22, 2000
01:48 | May 22, 2000
08:32 | 6 hours, 44 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Inspected and secured U.S.-built cargo crane known as the Orbital Replacement Unit Transfer Device, completed assembly of a Russian cargo crane called Strela, and replaced one of [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'']]'s two early communication antennas.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-101/sts-101-day-03-highlights.html|title=STS-101 Day 3 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=1999|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-101/sts-101-day-04-highlights.html|title=STS-101 Day 4 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2 |6. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-106]]
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Edward T. Lu]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Yuri Ivanovich Malenchenko]] | September 11, 2000
04:47 | September 11, 2000
11:01 | 6 hours, 14 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Attached cabling that integrated the [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'' module]] fully to the rest of the ISS, and constructed and attached a magnetometer that serves as a backup navigation system for the station.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-106/sts-106-day-03-highlights.html|title=STS-106 Day 3 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2 |7. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-92]]
EVA 1
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Leroy Chiao]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[William S. McArthur]] | October 15, 2000
14:27 | October 15, 2000
20:55 | 6 hours, 28 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Connected two sets of cables to provide power to heaters and conduits located on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Z1 truss|Z1 truss]], relocated two communication antenna assemblies, and installed a toolbox for use during future on-orbit construction.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-92/sts-92-day-05-highlights.html|title=STS-92 Day 5 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |8. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-92]]
EVA 2
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael E. Lopez-Alegria]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Peter J.K. Wisoff]] | October 16, 2000
14:15 | October 16, 2000
21:22 | 7 hours, 07 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed the [[Pressurized Mating Adapter]] (PMA)-3 docking port, and prepared the Z1 truss for the installation of the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar arrays]].{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-92/news/sts-92-mcc-11.txt|title=STS-92 Report #11|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |9. |rowspan=2 | [[STS-92]]
EVA 3
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Leroy Chiao]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[William S. McArthur]] | October 17, 2000
14:30 | October 17, 2000
21:18 | 6 hours, 48 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed two DC-to-DC converter units atop the station's Z1 Truss.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-92/sts-92-day-07-highlights.html|title=STS-92 Day 7 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |10. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-92]]
EVA 4
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael E. Lopez-Alegria]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Peter J.K. Wisoff]] | October 18, 2000
15:00 | October 18, 2000
21:56 | 6 hours, 56 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Removed a grapple fixture on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Z1 truss|Z1 truss]], deployed a Z1 utility tray, Manual Berthing Mechanism latches for Z1 were cycled and opened, and demonstrated the [[Simplified Aid For EVA Rescue]] (SAFER) pack's abilities.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-92/sts-92-day-08-highlights.html|title=STS-92 Day 8 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/shuttle/archives/sts-92/eva/|title=STS-92 Extravehicular Activities|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |11. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-97]]
EVA 1
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Joseph R. Tanner]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Carlos I. Noriega]] | December 3, 2000
18:35 | December 4, 2000
02:08 | 7 hours, 33 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Attached the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P6.2C S6 trusses|P6 truss]] to the Z1 Truss, and prepared the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar arrays]] for deployment. Prepared the radiator for the power system deployment.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/shuttle/archives/sts-97/eva/|title=STS-97 Extravehicular Activities|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-97/sts-97-day-04-highlights.html|title=STS-97 Day 4 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |12. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-97]]
EVA 2
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Joseph R. Tanner]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Carlos I. Noriega]] | December 5, 2000
17:21 | December 5, 2000
23:58 | 6 hours, 37 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Configured the space station to use power from the P6. Positioned the S-band antenna for use by the space station. Prepared the station for the arrival of the U. S. Laboratory, [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']].{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-97/sts-97-day-06-highlights.html|title=STS-97 Day 6 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |13. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-97]]
EVA 3
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Joseph R. Tanner]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Carlos I. Noriega]] | December 7, 2000
16:13 | December 7, 2000
21:23 | 5 hours, 10 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Positioned a floating potential probe to measure the plasma field surrounding the space station, performed repair work to increase tension in the starboard [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar array]] blankets that did not stretch out completely during deployment, and installed a centerline camera cable outside the [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'']] node.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-97/sts-97-day-08-highlights.html|title=STS-97 Day 8 Highlights|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2000|author=NASA}} |} ==2001== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | scope="col" width="100" | | scope="col" width="100" |
'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" |
'''Duration''' |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |14. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-98]]
EVA 1
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Thomas D. Jones]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert L. Curbeam]] | February 10, 2001
15:50 | February 10, 2001
23:24 | 7 hours, 34 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Removed protective launch covers and disconnected power and cooling cables between [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']] and ''Atlantis'', while crewmembers inside moved the {{convert|3800|cuft|m3|adj=on}} laboratory from the payload bay to its home on the [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'']] node. Curbeam and Jones then connected electrical, data and cooling lines to the lab, during which a small amount of [[ammonia]] crystals leaked from one of the hoses, prompting a decontamination procedure.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-98/sts-98-day-04-highlights.html|title=STS-98 Day 4 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.shuttlepresskit.com/STS-98/eva12.htm|title=Three Space Walks Will Add Sophisticated Laboratory|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=Shuttle Press Kits|date=2001|author=Boeing/NASA/United Space Alliance|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5dcM7GYnq?url=http://www.shuttlepresskit.com/STS-98/eva12.htm|archivedate=January 6, 2009|df=}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |15. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-98]]
EVA 2
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Thomas D. Jones]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert L. Curbeam]] | February 12, 2001
15:59 | February 12, 2001
22:49 | 6 hours, 50 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed the shuttle docking adapter onto [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']], installed insulating covers over the pins that held ''Destiny'' in place during launch, attached a vent to the lab's air system, installed handrails and sockets on the exterior of ''Destiny'', and attached a base for the future space station robotic arm.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-98/sts-98-day-06-highlights.html|title=STS-98 Day 6 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |16. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-98]]
EVA 3
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Thomas D. Jones]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert L. Curbeam]] | February 14, 2001
14:48 | February 14, 2001
20:13 | 5 hours, 25 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Attached a spare communications antenna to the station, double-checked connections between the ''Destiny'' lab and its docking port, released a cooling radiator on the station, inspected [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar array]] connections at the top of the station, and tested the ability of a spacewalker to carry an immobile crew member back to the shuttle airlock. This was the 100th U.S. spacewalk.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-98/sts-98-day-08-highlights.html|title=STS-98 Day 8 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |17. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-102]]
EVA 1
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[James S. Voss]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Susan J. Helms]] | March 11, 2001
05:12 | March 11, 2001
14:08 | 8 hours, 56 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Prepared Pressurized Mating Adapter-3 for repositioning from [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'']]’s Earth-facing berth to the port-side berth to make room for ''Leonardo'', the [[Italian Space Agency]]-built [[Multi-Purpose Logistics Module]]. Removed a Lab Cradle Assembly from the shuttle's cargo bay and installed it on the side of ''Destiny'', and installed a cable tray to ''Destiny'' for later use by the station’s robot arm. After re-entering the shuttle's airlock, Voss and Helms remained ready to assist if any troubles installing the docking port were encountered by the crew inside the shuttle. Longest space walk in shuttle history. |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |18. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-102]]
EVA 2
† | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Andrew S. W. Thomas]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Paul W. Richards]] | March 13, 2001
05:23 | March 13, 2001
11:44 | 6 hours, 21 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed an [[External Stowage Platform]] for spare station parts, attached a spare ammonia coolant pump to the platform, finished connecting several cables put in place on the first EVA for the station's robotic arm. Inspected a ''Unity'' node heater connection, and inspected of an exterior experiment, the Floating Potential Probe.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-102/sts-102-day-06-highlights.html|title=STS-102 Day 6 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |19. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-100]]
EVA 1
† | {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Chris Hadfield]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Scott E. Parazynski]] | April 22, 2001
11:45 | April 22, 2001
18:55 | 7 hours, 10 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed the station's [[UHF]] antenna, and the [[Canadian Space Agency]] made [[Canadarm2]]. Connected cables to give the arm power and allow it to accept computer commands from inside the lab. Hadfield became the first Canadian spacewalker.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-100/sts-100-day-04-highlights.html|title=STS-100 Day 4 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |20. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-100]]
EVA 2
† | {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Chris Hadfield]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Scott E. Parazynski]] | April 24, 2001
12:34 | April 24, 2001
20:14 | 7 hours, 40 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Connected the [[Power Data Grapple Fixture]] circuits for Canadarm2 onto [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']], removed an early communications antenna, transferred a spare Direct Current Switching Unit from the shuttle's payload bay to an equipment storage rack on the outside of ''Destiny''.{{Cite web|url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/missions/sts-100/sts-100-day-06-highlights.html|title=STS-100 Day 6 Highlights|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2001|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |21. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 2]]
‡ | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Yury Usachev]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[James Voss]] | June 8, 2001
14:21 | June 8, 2001
14:40 | 0 hours, 19 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed the docking cone onto the ''[[Zarya]]'' module, in preparation for the arrival of the Russian [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]]. 14:31 | October 12, 2002
20:35 | 6 hours, 04 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed a second camera system, released more radiator launch locks, removed insulation covers on quick-disconnect fittings near the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Z1 truss|Z1]] and P6 junction and to install Spool Positioning Devices, released starboard-side launch restraints on the CETA cart, and attached Ammonia Tank Assembly cables.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/johnson/news/shuttle/sts-112/STS-112-11.html|title=STS-112 Mission Control Center Status Report #11|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2002|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |46. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-112]]

00:46 | 6 hours, 10 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed fluid jumpers where the S0 and the P1 are attached to each other, removed the P1's starboard keel pin, installed another wireless video system External Transceiver Assembly onto the P1, and relocated the CETA cart from the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P1, S1 trusses|P1]]to the S1 truss.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/johnson/news/shuttle/sts-113/STS-113-11.html|title=STS-113 Mission Control Center Status Report #11|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2002|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |49. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-113]]

Mission managers decided to reschedule the spacewalk for June 30.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/station/crew/exp9/eva/index.html|title=Expedition 9 Spacewalks|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2004|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/spacenews/reports/issreports/2004/iss04-32.html|title=International Space Station Status Report #04-32|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2004|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |54. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 9]]

21:19 | July 1, 2004
02:59 | 5 hours, 40 minutes |- |colspan=4 |Replaced a Remote Power Controller (RPC) that failed in late April, causing a loss of power in [[Control Moment Gyroscope]] No. 2 (CMG 2).{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/spacenews/reports/issreports/2004/iss04-36.html|title=International Space Station Status Report #04-36|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2004|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |55. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 9]]

Installed two antennas, and removed and replaced ''Kromka'' experiment packages.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/spacenews/reports/issreports/2004/iss04-43.html|title=International Space Station Status Report #04-43|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2004|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |56. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 9]]

{{flagicon|USA}} [[Stephen K. Robinson]] | July 30, 2005
09:48 | July 30, 2005
17:36 | 6 hours, 50 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Demonstrated shuttle [[Space Shuttle thermal protection system|thermal protection]] repair techniques and enhancements to the Station's attitude control system. installed a base and cabling for an [[External Stowage Platform]], rerouted power to [[Control Moment Gyroscope]]-2 (CMG-2), retrieved two exposure experiments, and replaced a faulty [[global positioning system]] antenna on the station.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/returntoflight/news/STS-114-09.html|title=STS-114 MCC Status Report #09|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2005|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |60. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-114]]

† | {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Soichi Noguchi]]

08:42 | August 1, 2005
15:56 | 7 hours, 14 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Removed faulty CMG-1 from the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Z1 truss|Z1 truss]], installed faulty CMG-1 into [[Space Shuttle Discovery|''Discovery'']]'s payload bay, and installed new CMG-1 onto the Z1 truss segment.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/returntoflight/news/STS-114-13.html|title=STS-114 MCC Status Report #13|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2005|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/050801_sts114_eva2.html|title=Shuttle Astronauts Repair ISS Gyroscope in Second Spacewalk |accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=Space.com|date=2005|first=Tariq|last=Malik}} |- |rowspan=2|61. |rowspan=2|[[STS-114]]

08:48 | August 3, 2005
14:49 | 6 hours, 1 minute |- | colspan=4|Photographed and inspected ''Discovery''’s heat shield, removed two protruding gap fillers from between tiles in the forward area of the orbiter’s underside, and installed [[amateur radio satellite]] PCSAT2.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/returntoflight/news/STS-114-17.html|title=STS-114 MCC Status Report #17|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2005|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |62. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 11]]

* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergei Krikalev]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[John L. Phillips]] | August 18, 2005
19:02 | August 19, 2005
00:00 | 4 hours, 58 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Retrieved one of three canisters from the Biorisk experiment, removed Micro-Particles Capturer experiment and Space Environment Exposure Device from [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']], retrieved ''Matroska'' experiment, installed an [[Automated Transfer Vehicle]] (ATV) docking television camera.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition11/exp11_spacewalk.html|title=Station Crew Completes Spacewalk|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2005|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/spacenews/reports/issreports/2005/iss05-40.html|title=International Space Station Status Report #05-40|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2005|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |63. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 12]]
EVA 1 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[William S. McArthur]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Valery Tokarev]] | November 7, 2005
15:32 | November 7, 2005
20:54 | 5 hours, 22 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed and set up the P1 Truss camera, retrieved a failed Rotary Joint Motor Controller (RJMC), jettisoned a Floating Potential Probe, and removed and replaced a remote power controller module on the [[Canadarm2#Mobile Base System|Mobile Transporter]]. First [[Quest Joint Airlock|''Quest'']] airlock-based spacewalk since April 2003.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight.nasa.gov/spacenews/reports/issreports/2005/iss05-55.html|title=International Space Station Status Report #05-55|accessdate=October 7, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2005|author=NASA}} |} ==2006== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | scope="col" width="100" | | scope="col" width="100" |

* |{{flagicon|USA}} [[William S. McArthur]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Valery Tokarev]] | February 3, 2006
9:55 | February 3, 2006
16:27 | 5 hours, 43 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Released [[SuitSat-1]], retrieved the Biorisk experiment, photographed a sensor for a micrometeoroid experiment, relocated an adapter for a small crane, and tied off the surviving [[Umbilical cable|umbilical]] of the [[Canadarm2#Mobile Base System|Mobile Transporter]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition12/exp12_eva2.html|title=Crew Back in Station After Spacewalk|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2|65. |rowspan=2|[[Expedition 13]]

{{flagicon|USA}} [[Jeffrey Williams (astronaut)|Jeffrey Williams]] |June 1, 2006
23:48 |June 2, 2006
06:19 | 6 hours, 31 minutes |- | colspan=4|Repaired a vent for the station's oxygen-producing Elektron unit, retrieved a Biorisk experiment, retrieved a contamination-monitoring device from [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']], and replaced a malfunctioning camera on the [[Canadarm2#Mobile Base System|Mobile Base System]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition13/eva1.html|title=Station Crew Winds Up Successful Spacewalk|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |66. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-121]]
EVA 1 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Piers Sellers]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael E. Fossum]] |July 8, 2006
13:17 |July 8, 2006
20:48 | 7 hours, 31 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed a blade blocker in the zenith Interface Umbilical Assembly (IUA) to protect the undamaged power, data and video cable, rerouted the cable to prepare for the second EVA. Tested the combination of the [[Canadarm|Space Shuttle Canadarm(SRMS)]] and the [[Orbiter Boom Sensor System]] (OBSS) as a platform for astronauts to make repairs to a damaged orbiter.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts121/news/STS-121-09.html|title=STS-121 MCC Status Report #09 |accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |67. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-121]]
EVA 2 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Piers Sellers]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael E. Fossum]] |July 10, 2006
12:14 |July 10, 2006
19:01 | 6 hours, 47 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Restored the International Space Station's [[Canadarm2#Mobile Base System|Mobile Transporter]] rail car to full operation, and delivered a spare pump module for the station's cooling system. Sellers' SAFER pack came loose during the EVA, requiring Fossum to stop twice during the spacewalk to secure the pack with safety tethers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts121/news/STS-121-13.html|title=STS-121 MCC Status Report #13|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2|68. |rowspan=2|[[STS-121]]
EVA 3 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Piers Sellers]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael E. Fossum]] |July 12, 2006
7:11 |July 12, 2006
13:31 | 7 hours, 11 minutes |- | colspan=4|Used an infrared camera to shoot 20 seconds of video of selected [[reinforced carbon-carbon]] (RCC) panels on the shuttle wing's leading edge, and then moved to the payload bay to test a shuttle tile repair material known as NOAX on pre-damaged shuttle tiles that were flown in a test container.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts121/news/STS-121-17.html|title=STS-121 MCC Status Report #17|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- |rowspan=2|69. |rowspan=2|[[Expedition 13]]
EVA 2 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Jeffrey Williams (astronaut)|Jeffrey Williams]]
{{flagicon|GER}} [[Thomas Reiter]] |August 3, 2006
14:04 |August 3, 2006
19:58 | 5 hours, 54 minutes |- | colspan=4|Installed: The Floating Potential Measurement Unit (FPMU), two materials on [[Materials International Space Station Experiment]] (MISSE) containers, a controller for a thermal radiator rotary joint on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P1.2C S1 trusses|S1 truss]], a starboard jumper and spool positioning device (SPD) on S1, a light on the truss railway handcart, and installed and replaced a malfunctioning GPS antenna. Tested an infrared camera designed to detect damage in a shuttle's [[reinforced carbon-carbon]] (RCC) thermal protection tiles. Inspection and photography of a scratch on the [[Quest Joint Airlock|''Quest'']] airlock hatch.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition13/exp13_eva_08_03_2006.html|title=Station Crewmen Back Inside After Spacewalk|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |70. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-115]]
EVA 1 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Tanner]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper]] |September 12, 2006
10:17 |September 12, 2006
15:43 | 6 hours, 26 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Initial installation of the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P3.2FP4.2C S3.2FS4 truss assemblies|P3/P4 truss]] onto the space station. Connected power cables on the truss, released the launch restraints on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar array]] blanket box, the Beta Gimbal Assembly, and the solar array wings. Configured the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar alpha rotary joint|Solar Alpha Rotary Joint]] (SARJ), and removed two circuit interrupt devices to prepare for [[STS-116]]. Piper became the seventh American woman to conduct a spacewalk.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts115/news/STS-115-07.html|title=STS-115 MCC Status Report #07 |accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |71. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-115]]
EVA 2 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Dan Burbank]]
{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Steven MacLean (astronaut)|Steve MacLean]] |September 13, 2006
9:05 |September 13, 2006
16:16 | 7 hours, 11 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Continued installation of the P3/4 truss onto the station, and activated the SARJ.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts115/news/STS-115-09.html|title=STS-115 MCC Status Report #09|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2|72. |rowspan=2|[[STS-115]]
EVA 3 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Tanner]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper]] |September 15, 2006
10:00 |September 15, 2006
16:42 | 6 hours, 42 minutes |- | colspan=4|Installed a radiator onto the P3/4 truss, powered up a cooling radiator for the new [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar arrays]], replaced an S-Band radio antenna, and installed insulation for another antenna. Tanner took photos of the shuttle's wings using an infrared camera to test the camera's ability to detect damage.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts115/news/STS-115-13.html|title=STS-115 MCC Status Report #13|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- |rowspan=2|73. |rowspan=2|[[Expedition 14]]
EVA 1
* |{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Mikhail Tyurin]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Lopez-Alegria]] |November 22, 2006
23:17 |November 23, 2006
04:55 | 5 hours, 38 minutes |- | colspan=4|"Orbiting golf shot" event sponsored by a Canadian golf company through the [[Russian Federal Space Agency]]. Lopez-Alegria put the tee on the ladder outside [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'']], while Tyurin set up a camera, and then performed the golf shot. Inspected and photographed a Kurs antenna on Progress 23, relocated an [[Automated Transfer Vehicle]] (ATV) WAL antenna, installed a BTN neutron experiment, and jettisoned two thermal covers from the BTN.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition14/exp14_eva_112206.html|title=Spacewalkers Tee Off on Science, Mechanics|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |74. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-116]]
EVA 1 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert Curbeam]]
{{flagicon|SWE}} [[Christer Fuglesang]] |December 12, 2006
20:31 |December 13, 2006
03:07 | 6 hours, 36 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed the [[ISS]] [[Integrated Truss Structure|P5 Truss]], and replaced a video camera on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P1.2C S1 trusses|S1 truss]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts116/news/STS-116-07.html|title=STS-116 MCC Status Report #07 |accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |75. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-116]]
EVA 2 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert Curbeam]]
{{flagicon|SWE}} [[Christer Fuglesang]] |December 14, 2006
19:41 |December 15, 2006
00:41 | 5 hours, 00 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Reconfigured the station's electrical wiring, channels 2–3 on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P3.2FP4.2C S3.2FS4 truss assemblies|P3/P4 truss]] to take advantage of the new [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar arrays]], relocated two handcarts that run along rails on the station's main truss, put a thermal cover on the station's robotic arm, and installed bags of tools for future spacewalkers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts116/news/STS-116-11.html|title=STS-116 MCC Status Report #11|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |76. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-116]]
EVA 3 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert Curbeam]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]] |December 16, 2006
19:25 |December 17, 2006
02:57 | 7 hours, 31 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Completed rewiring the station's electrical system, circuits 1 and 4, to take advantage of the P3/P4 solar array power, installed a robotic arm grapple fixture, and positioned three bundles of Russian debris shield panels outside [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']]. Additional time was spent trying to help retract the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P6.2C S6 trusses|P6]] [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar array]] panel by shaking the panel's blanket box from its base. (Williams became the 8th American woman to perform an EVA, and the 9th woman spacewalker.){{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts116/news/STS-116-15.html|title=STS-116 MCC Status Report #15|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |77. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-116]]
EVA 4 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert Curbeam]]
{{flagicon|SWE}} [[Christer Fuglesang]] |December 18, 2006
19:00 |December 19, 2006
01:38 | 6 hours, 38 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Assisted ground controllers with retracting the P6 solar array panels. Curbeam, on his seventh spacewalk, set a single-flight EVA record with four spacewalks in a single shuttle mission.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts116/news/STS-116-19.html|title=STS-116 MCC Status Report #19|accessdate=October 21, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2006|author=NASA}} |} ==2007== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | | scope="col" width="100" |

EVA 2 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Lopez-Alegria]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]] |January 31, 2007
15:14 |January 31, 2007
23:09 | 7 hours, 55 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Reconfigured one of the two cooling loops serving [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']] from the temporary to permanent system, connected a cable for the [[Station-to-Shuttle Power Transfer System]] (SSPTS), installed six cable cinches and two winch bars to secure the [[starboard]] radiator of the P6 Truss, and then installed a shroud over it. Removed one of two fluid lines from the Early Ammonia Servicer (EAS) on the P6 Truss. The EAS would be jettisoned during a later EVA.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition14/exp14_eva6.html|title=Station Crew Members Wind Up Successful Spacewalk|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2007|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |79. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 14]]
EVA 3 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Lopez-Alegria]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]] |February 4, 2007
13:38 |February 4, 2007
20:49 | 7 hours, 11 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Reconfigured the second of the two cooling loops serving ''Destiny'' from the temporary to permanent system, completed work with the Early Ammonia Servicer (EAS) on the P6 Truss, photographed the inboard end of the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P6.2C S6 trusses|P6]] starboard solar wing in preparation for its retraction during [[STS-117]], removed a sunshade from a multiplexer-demultiplexer data relay device, and continued work on the SSPTS.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition14/exp14_eva7.html|title=Crew Completes Scheduled Spacewalk Tasks, and More|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2007|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |80. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 14]]
EVA 4 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Lopez-Alegria]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]] |February 8, 2007
13:26 |February 8, 2007
20:06 | 6 hours, 40 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Removed two thermal shrouds on two Rotary Joint Motor Controllers (RJMC) on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P3.2FP4.2C S3.2FS4 truss assemblies|P3]] truss, removed two large shrouds from P3 Bays 18 and 20, and jettisoned the shrouds away from the station. Deployed an Unpressurized Cargo Carrier Assembly Attachment System (UCCAS) on the upper face of the P3 truss, removed two launch locks from the P5 truss, and connected four cables of the SSPTS to the [[Pressurized Mating Adapter]] (PMA-2) at the forward end of [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']] where shuttles dock.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition14/exp14_eva8.html|title=Spacewalkers Successfully Wrap Up Record Series|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2007|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |81. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 14]]

* |{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Mikhail Tyurin]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Lopez-Alegria]] |February 22, 2007
10:27 |February 22, 2007
16:45 | 6 hours, 18 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Retracted the antenna of the Progress cargo carrier at the aft port of the [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']] service module, photographed a Russian satellite navigation antenna, and replaced a Russian materials experiment, inspected and photographed an antenna for the [[Automated Transfer Vehicle]] (ATV), photographed a German robotics experiment, and inspected, remated, and photographed hardware connectors.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition14/exp14_eva17.html|title=Spacewalkers Successfully Retract Progress Antenna|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2007|author=NASA}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |82. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 15]]

* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Fyodor Yurchikhin]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Kotov]] | May 30, 2007
19:05 | May 31, 2007
00:30 | 5 hours, 25 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed Service Module Debris Protection (SMDP) panels and rerouted a [[Global Positioning System]] antenna cable.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition15/exp15_eva18.html|title=Spacewalk Complete, Debris Panels Installed|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2007|author=NASA}} |- |rowspan=2|83. |rowspan=2|[[Expedition 15]]

01:22 | 7 hours, 58 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Repaired the [[Orbital Maneuvering System]] (OMS) pod thermal blanket, finished the [[Integrated Truss Structure#P6.2C S6 trusses|P6]] [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar arrays|solar array]] retraction, and installed a hydrogen ventilation valve onto [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']].{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2007/06/success-filled-day-for-sts-117s-eva-3/|title=Success filled day for STS-117’s EVA-3|accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA SpaceFlight.com |date=2007|first=Chris|last=Bergin}} |- |rowspan=2|87. |rowspan=2|[[STS-117]]

16:25 | June 17, 2007
22:54 | 6 hours, 29 minutes |- | colspan=4|Retrieved a television camera and its support structure from an [[External Stowage Platform]] attached to the [[Quest Joint Airlock|''Quest'']] airlock, and installed it on the S3 truss, verified the Drive Lock Assembly (DLA) 2 configuration, and removed the last six SARJ launch restraints. EVA 3 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard Mastracchio]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Clay Anderson]] | August 15, 2007
14:38 | August 15, 2007
20:05 | 5 hours, 28 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Moved two Crew Equipment Translation Aid (CETA) carts from tracks on the left side of the [[Canadarm2]] [[Canadarm2#Mobile Base System|Mobile Transporter]] to its right side. Relocated an antenna base from the P6 truss to P1, and installed a new transponder and signal processor for an S-band communications upgrade. During the EVA, Mastracchio noted a hole in the second layer of material on the thumb of his left glove. The suit has five protective layers, and the small hole did not cause any danger to Mastracchio, but he returned to the airlock early as a precautionary measure.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/shuttlemissions/sts118/news/STS-118-15.html|title=STS-118 MCC Status Report #15 |accessdate=October 6, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2007|author=NASA}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |92. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-118]]

{{flagicon|USA}} [[Stephen G. Bowen]] | November 18, 2008
18:09 | November 19, 2008
01:01 | 6 hours, 52 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Transferred an empty nitrogen tank assembly from ESP3 to the shuttle's cargo bay, transferred a new flex hose rotary coupler to ESP3 for future use, removed an insulation cover on the [[Japanese Experiment Module#Exposed Facility|''Kibo'' External Facility]] berthing mechanism, began cleaning and lubrication of the starboard [[Solar Alpha Rotary Joint|SARJ]], and replacement of its 11 trundle bearing assemblies.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/main/rss_feed_above_snip_collection_archive_1.html|title=Astronauts Resume Spacewalk After Tools Lost|accessdate=November 18, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=2008|first=NASA|last=RSS}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflightnow.com/shuttle/sts126/081118fd5/index2.html|title=Bag of tools escapes from spacewalker and floats away|accessdate=November 18, 2008|publisher=Spaceflightnow.com|date=2008|author=William Harwood for CBS News}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |116. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-126]]

00:31 | 6 hours, 7 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Completed replacement of trundle bearing assemblies on starboard SARJ, lubricated the port SARJ, installed a video camera, re‐installed insulation covers on the Kibo External Facility berthing mechanism, performed Kibo robotic arm grounding tab maintenance, installed spacewalk handrails on Kibo, installed Global Positioning Satellite (GPS) antennae on Kibo, photographed radiators, and photographed trailing umbilical system cables.{{Cite web|url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewsr.html?pid=29934|title=ISS On-Orbit Status 11/25/08|accessdate=November 25, 2008|publisher=NASA|date=November 25, 2008|author=NASA}}{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflightnow.com/shuttle/sts126/081124fd11/index4.html|title=Spacewalk No. 4 ends|accessdate=November 24, 2008|publisher=Spaceflightnow.com|date=November 24, 2008|author=William Harwood for CBS News}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |119. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 18]]

21:11 | 4 hours, 49 minutes |- | colspan=4|Installed the EXPOSE-R onto the universal science platform of the ''[[Zvezda (ISS module)|Zvezda]]'' module, removed tape straps from the area of the docking target on the ''[[Pirs (ISS module)|Pirs]]'' airlock and docking compartment, inspected and photographed the exterior of the Russian portion of the station.{{Cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-10-voa62.cfm |title=Space Station Astronauts Complete Space Walk Ahead of Shuttle Launch |accessdate=March 11, 2009 |publisher=Voice of America |date=March 10, 2009 |first=Brian |last=Wagner |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313000132/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-10-voa62.cfm |archivedate=March 13, 2009 |df= }} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |121. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-119]]

21:49 | September 2, 2009
04:24 | 6 hours, 35 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Prepared for the replacement of an empty ammonia tank on the station's port truss by releasing its bolts. Retrieved the [[Materials International Space Station Experiment|MISSE-6]] and [[European Technology Exposure Facility|EuTEF]] experiments mounted outside of [[Columbus (ISS module)|''Columbus'']], and stowed them in the Shuttle's payload bay for their return to Earth. (Stott became the 9th American woman to perform an EVA, and the 10th woman spacewalker.) |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |132. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-128]]

20:39 | September 6, 2009
03:40 | 7 hours, 1 minute |- | colspan=4 |Prepared for the arrival of [[Tranquility (ISS module)|''Tranquility'']] by attaching cables between the starboard truss and Unity, the area where Tranquility will be installed. The spacewalkers also replaced a communications sensor device, installed two new GPS antennas, deployed the PAS on the S3 truss, and replaced a circuit breaker. |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |134. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-129]]

{{flagicon|USA}} [[Nicholas Patrick]] | February 12, 2010
02:17 | February 12, 2010
08:49 | 6 hours, 32 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Removed a protective cover on a port on the [[Unity (ISS module)|''Unity'' node]] where [[Tranquility (ISS module)|''Tranquility'']] was berthed halfway through the spacewalk. The pair then transferred a spare parts platform for the [[Special Purpose Dexterous Manipulator]] from the shuttle to the station. | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Robert L. Behnken]]

02:20 | February 14, 2010
08:14 | 5 hours, 54 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed ammonia plumbing and connectors between ''Unity'', [[Destiny (ISS module)|''Destiny'']] and ''Tranquility'' and covered them with thermal insulation. {{flagicon|USA}} [[Nicholas Patrick]] | February 17, 2010
02:15 | February 17, 2010
08:03 | 5 hours, 48 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed additional ammonia plumbing between ''Unity'' and ''Tranquility'', removed insulation and launch locks from the Cupola, installed additional handrails on the exterior of ''Tranquility'' and performed get-ahead tasks to support the installation of a PDGF on the exterior of ''[[Zarya]]'' with cable installation on ''Unity'' and the S0 truss. |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |141. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-131]]
EVA 1
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard Mastracchio]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Clayton Anderson]] | April 9, 2010
05:31 | April 9, 2010
11:58 | 6 hours, 27 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Relocated new ammonia tank from the Shuttle's payload bay to a temporary stowage location and disconnected the fluid lines to the old ammonia tank on the S1 truss. Retrieved a Japanese seed experiment from the exterior of the [[Japanese Experiment Module|''Kibo'']] laboratory for return to earth and replaced a failed gyroscope on the S0 truss. Performed get-ahead tasks including the opening of a window flap on the zenith CBM of [[Harmony (ISS module)|''Harmony'']], and removed launch restraint bolts from a Flex Hose Rotary Coupler (FHRC) on the P1 truss. |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |142. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-131]]
EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard Mastracchio]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Clayton Anderson]] | April 11, 2010
05:20 | April 11, 2010
12:56 | 7 hours, 26 minutes |- | colspan=4 |The old ammonia tank was removed from the S1 truss and was replaced with the new tank. The electrical connections to the tank were made, but the fluid lines were deferred to the mission's third EVA due to time constraints since the installation was prolonged by a problem with the bolts that hold the tank to the truss. The old tank was relocated to a temporary stowage location on the station and a foot restraint was relocated in preparation for a future shuttle mission's spacewalk. |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |143. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-131]]
EVA 3
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard Mastracchio]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Clayton Anderson]] | April 13, 2010
06:14 | April 13, 2010
12:36 | 6 hours, 24 minutes |- | colspan=4 |The fluid lines were connected to the new ammonia tank and the old tank was moved to the shuttle's payload bay for return to Earth. Micro-meteoroid debris shields from the ''Quest'' airlock which were no longer necessary were brought inside the airlock for return to Earth inside the [[Multi-Purpose Logistics Module|''Leonardo'' MPLM]]. The Z1 truss was prepared for the installation of a spare antenna on the next shuttle mission, and a foot restraint was relocated in preparation for a future spacewalk. The retrieval of an external carrier plate on [[Columbus (ISS module)|''Columbus'']] was deferred to another shuttle mission due to time constraints after problems were encountered with attaching the old ammonia tank to a carrier in the payload bay, and several other tasks were deferred to later EVAs due to the replanning from the problems with the mission's second EVA. |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |144. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-132]]
