{{flagicon|USA}} [[Stephen G. Bowen]] | May 17, 2010
11:54 | May 17, 2010
19:19 | 7 hours, 25 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed a spare space-to-ground [[Ku-band]] antenna on the [[Integrated Truss Structure#Z1 truss|Z1 truss]]; installed new tool platform on [[Dextre]], and broke torque on bolts holding replacement batteries to the ICC-VLD cargo carrier. |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |145. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-132]]
EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Stephen G. Bowen]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael T. Good]] | May 19, 2010
10:38 | May 19, 2010
17:47 | 7 hours, 9 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Repaired ''Atlantis''{{'}} [[Orbiter Boom Sensor System]] (OBSS); [[Integrated Truss Structure#P6.2C S6 trusses|P6]] battery replacement (4 of 6 units); and removed gimbal locks from the Ku-band antenna installed on the first EVA of the mission. |- |rowspan=2|146. |rowspan=2|[[STS-132]]
EVA 3
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael T. Good]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Garrett Reisman]] | May 21, 2010
10:27 | May 21, 2010
17:13 | 6 hours, 46 minutes |- | colspan=4|P6 battery replacement (final 2 of 6 units); installed ammonia "jumpers" at the P4/P5 interface; retrieved a spare PDGF from ''Atlantis''{{'}} payload bay and stowed it inside the ''Quest'' airlock. The spacewalkers also replenished supplies of EVA tools in toolboxes on the exterior of the station. |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |147. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 24]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Fyodor Yurchikhin]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Mikhail Korniyenko]] | July 27, 2010
04:11 | July 27, 2010
10:53 | 6 hours, 42 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Replaced ATV docking camera on ''Zvezda''{{'s}} rear docking port, added cables from the ''Zvezda'' and ''Zarya'' modules to connect ''Rassvet'' to the Russian command and data handling computer system, added cables between ''Rassvet'' and ''Zarya'' to allow use of the KURS automated docking system on ''Rassvet''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition24/russian_eva25.html|title=Cosmonauts Complete First Expedition 24 Spacewalk|last=NASA |date=July 28, 2010|publisher=NASA|accessdate=October 30, 2010}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |148. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 24]]
EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Douglas H. Wheelock]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Tracy Caldwell Dyson]] | August 7, 2010
11:19 | August 7, 2010
19:22 | 8 hours, 3 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Attempted to replace a failed ammonia pump module located on the S1 truss. Due to an ammonia leak in the final line that needed to be disconnected from the failed pump module, the planned tasks were only partially completed, and the spacewalkers needed extra time to perform a "bake out" to ensure no ammonia entered the station following the EVA. This was the longest International Space Station-based spacewalk, and the sixth longest spacewalk in history.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/main/080710_spacewalk.html|title=Expedition 24 Performs First Spacewalk to Replace Ammonia Pump|last=NASA |date=August 7, 2010|publisher=NASA|accessdate=October 30, 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2010/08/live-critical-iss-spacewalk-replace-coolant-pump/|title=Opening ISS spacewalk to replace coolant pump completed|accessdate=August 7, 2010|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|first=Chris|last=Bergin}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |149. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 24]]
EVA 3
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Douglas H. Wheelock]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Tracy Caldwell Dyson]] | August 11, 2010
12:27 | August 11, 2010
19:53 | 7 hours, 26 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Completed removal of failed pump module from the S1 truss and began installation preparations on the replacement pump.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition24/081110_spacewalk.html|title=Expedition 24 Performs Second Spacewalk to Replace Ammonia Pump|last=NASA |date=August 11, 2010|publisher=NASA|accessdate=October 30, 2010}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |150. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 24]]
EVA 4
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Douglas H. Wheelock]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Tracy Caldwell Dyson]] | August 16, 2010
10:20 | August 16, 2010
17:40 | 7 hours, 20 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Completion of the third contingency spacewalk to install a spare ammonia pump module on the S1 Truss.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition24/081610_spacewalk.html|title=Spacewalkers Install Spare Ammonia Pump|last=NASA |date=August 16, 2010|publisher=NASA|accessdate=October 30, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/network/news/space/home/spacenews/files/858570ea840dbbbe70597a57f78b8a67-51.html|title=Astronauts wrap up successful repair EVA|last=Harwood|first=William|date=August 16, 2010|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=October 30, 2010}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |151. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 25]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Fyodor Yurchikhin]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Skripochka]] | November 15, 2010
14:55 | November 15, 2010
21:22 | 6 hours, 27 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed: portable multipurpose workstation in Zvezda Plane IV; struts between Poisk and Zvezda and Zarya modules; hand-rail on Pirs docking module; SKK #1-M2 cassette on Poisk module. Removed: Plasma Pulse Injector Science hardware and Expose-R scientific experiment from portable multipurpose workstation in Zvezda Plane II; Kontur science hardware (ROKVISS); TV camera from Rassvet module. Performed Test experiment to check for microorganisms or contamination underneath insulation on the Russian ISS segment.{{cite web|url=http://www.federalspace.ru/main.php?id=2&nid=10834|title=Russian Cosmonauts Returned to the ISS after EVA|publisher=Russian Federal Space Agency|date=November 16, 2010|accessdate=November 16, 2010}} Cosmonauts failed to relocate TV camera due to interference from insulation at installation location.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/living/index.html|title=Crew completes spacewalk|author=NASA|date=November 15, 2010|accessdate=November 16, 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/international-space-station-russian-spacewalk-wrap-101115.html|title=Spacewalking Cosmonauts Upgrade International Space Station|publisher=Space.com|first=Clara|last=Moskowitz|date=November 15, 2010|accessdate=July 14, 2012}} |- |} ==2011== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | | scope="col" width="100" |
'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" |
'''Duration''' |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |152. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 26]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Dmitri Kondratyev]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Skripochka]] | January 21, 2011
14:29 | January 21, 2011
19:52 | 5 hours, 23 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed an experimental communication antenna on ''Zvezda'' 's nadir side, removed and stowed a failed plasma pulse generator experiment apparatus and a material exposure experiment from ''Zvezda'', and installed a docking TV camera on the ''[[Rassvet (ISS module)|Rassvet]]'' module.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2011/01/iss-crew-2011-spacewalk-marathon-27th-russian-eva/|title=ISS Crew open 2011 spacewalk marathon with 27th Russian EVA|first=Pete|last=Harding|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=March 6, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition26/russian_eva27.html|title=Cosmonauts Perform 27th Russian Space Station Spacewalk|author=NASA|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=March 6, 2011}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |153. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 26]]
EVA 2
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Dmitri Kondratyev]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Skripochka]] | February 16, 2011
13:30 | February 16, 2011
18:21 | 4 hours, 51 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Installed two experiments for Earth seismic and lightning observations on the ''Zvezda'' module, removed two material exposure experiment panels from the exterior of the ''Zarya'' module, and jettisoned a foot restraint overboard.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2011/02/cosmonauts-perform-russian-spacewalk-on-iss/|title=Cosmonauts complete Russian Spacewalk on ISS|first=Pete|last=Harding|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=March 6, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition26/russian_eva28.html|title=Cosmonauts Perform 28th Russian Space Station Spacewalk|author=NASA|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=March 6, 2011}} |- | colspan=6 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |154. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-133]]
EVA 1
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Stephen Bowen (astronaut)|Stephen Bowen]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Alvin Drew]] | February 28, 2011
15:46 | February 28, 2011
22:20 | 6 hours, 34 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Drew and Bowen installed a power extension cable between the Unity and Tranquility nodes to provide a contingency power source should it be required. The spacewalkers then moved the failed ammonia pump module that was replaced in August from its temporary location to the External Stowage Platform 2 adjacent to the Quest airlock. Drew and Bowen then installed a wedge under a camera on the S3 truss to provide clearance from the newly installed ELC-4. They next replaced a guide for the rail cart system used for moving the station robotic arm along the truss. The guides had been removed when astronauts were performing work on the station's starboard Solar Alpha Rotary Joint (SARJ), which rotates the solar arrays to track the sun. The final task was to "fill" a special bottle with the vacuum of space for a Japanese education payload. The bottle will be part of a public museum exhibit. |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |155. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-133]]
EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Stephen Bowen (astronaut)|Stephen Bowen]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Alvin Drew]] | March 2, 2011
15:42 | March 2, 2011
21:56 | 6 hours, 14 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Drew removed thermal insulation from a platform, while Bowen swapped out an attachment bracket on the Columbus module. Bowen then installed a camera assembly on the Dextre robot and removed insulation from Dextre's electronics platform. Drew installed a light on a cargo cart and repaired some dislodged thermal insulation from a valve on the truss. |- | colspan=6 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |156. |rowspan=2 |[[STS-134]]
EVA 1 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Andrew Feustel]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Gregory Chamitoff]] | 20 May 2011
07:10 | 20 May 2011
13:29 | 6 hours, 19 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Feustel and Chamitoff retrieved the two [[Materials International Space Station Experiment|MISSE 7 experiments]] and installed a new package of MISSE 8 experiments on [[Express Logistics Carrier|ELC-2]], which was already on the station. They installed jumpers between segments on the left-side truss, or backbone of the station, for [[ammonia]] refills; vented [[nitrogen]] from an ammonia servicer; they began to install an external wireless communication antenna on the [[Destiny (ISS module)|Destiny laboratory]] that will provide wireless communication to the Express Logistics Carriers mounted on the station's truss, but was cut short due to a bad [[Carbon dioxide|CO2]] sensor in Chamitoff's suit. |- | rowspan=2 |157. | rowspan=2 |[[STS-134]]
EVA 2 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Andrew Feustel]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Fincke]] | 22 May 2011
6:05 | 22 May 2011
14:12 | 8 hours, 7 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Feustel and Fincke refilled the Port 6 (P5) radiators with ammonia. They completed venting the early ammonia system, lubricated the port solar alpha rotary joint and parts of [[Dextre]], a two-armed space station robot capable of handling delicate assembly tasks currently performed by spacewalkers. Fincke also installed grapple bars on the port radiators. |- | rowspan=2 |158. | rowspan=2 |[[STS-134]]
EVA 3 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Andrew Feustel]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Fincke]] | 25 May 2011
05:43 | 25 May 2011
12:37 | 6 hours, 54 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Feustel and Fincke installed a grapple fixture (a handle for the station's [[Canadarm2]] to grab on to) on the [[Zarya (ISS module)|''Zarya'' module]], to support robotic operations based from the Russian segment. They also installed additional cables to provide backup power to the Russian portion of the space station. The pair finished installing the wireless video system that was left unfinished during EVA 1. |- | rowspan=2 |159. | rowspan=2 |[[STS-134]]
EVA 4 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Fincke]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Gregory Chamitoff]] | 27 May 2011
04:15 | 27 May 2011
11:39 | 7 hours, 24 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Fincke and Chamitoff stowed the shuttle's 50-foot [[Orbiter Boom Sensor System]] (OBSS) on the right-side truss on a permanent stowage fixture. The pair then retrieved a grapple from the station's left-side truss and used it as a replacement for the grapple currently on the boom. They then released restraints from one of the arms spare arms for Dextre and replaced thermal insulation on one of the spare gas tanks for the [[Quest Joint Airlock|Quest airlock]]. The arrival of the PMM module marked the completion of the US Orbital Segment.{{Cite web|url=http://www.space.com/11807-endeaovur-sts134-spacewalk-shuttle-astronauts.html|title=Astronauts Complete Space Station in 4th, Final Spacewalk|publisher=Space.com|first=Denise|last=Chow|date=May 27, 2011|accessdate=July 14, 2012}} This was the final EVA from the Space Shuttle before its retirement. |- | colspan=6 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |160. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 28]]
EVA 1 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Ronald J. Garan, Jr.]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael E. Fossum]] | 12 July 2011
13:22 | 12 July 2011
19:53 | 6 hours, 31 minutes |- | colspan=4 |This spacewalk was kind of special in that it was the last spacewalk performed while a space shuttle was docked to the station. However, other than the previous spacewalks during docked operations, this one was performed by the station crew and not by the space shuttle crew. The need for this spacewalk arose since a failed pump module on the station should be returned for inspection to the ground on the space shuttle. This having been the main objective done during this EVA the spacewalkers also installed a Robotic Refueling Mission experiment and fully deployed the [[Materials International Space Station Experiment|MISSE 8 experiment]] (which was only half deployed during a previous spacewalk).{{Cite web|url=http://www.space-travel.com/reports/Astronauts_Complete_Spacewalk_Cargo_Transfers_Begin_999.html|title=Astronauts Complete Spacewalk;Cargo Transfers Begin|publisher=space-travel.com|author=Staff Writers|date=July 13, 2011|accessdate=July 29, 2012}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/566071main_135_press_kit2.pdf|title=STS-135: The Final Mission Press Kit/July 2011|publisher=NASA|author=NASA|date=July 2011|accessdate=July 29, 2012}} |- | rowspan=2 |161. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 28]]
EVA 2* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Alexandrovich Volkov|Sergei Volkov]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Aleksandr Samokutyayev]] | 3 August 2011
14:50 | 3 August 2011
21:13 | 6 hours, 23 minutes |- | colspan=4 |The spacewalkers installed laser communications equipment which eventually will test transmissions of up to 100 MB/s of Russian science data with the ground on the Zvezda service module. Radioskaf-V a small satellite for a student experiment was deployed and an antenna which was used for the docking of Poisk was removed and brought back into the station. As part of the research work on the station the BIORISK experiment was installed on a handrail outside Pirs. Last but not least photographs were taken including some of an antenna with signs of degraded performance to support engineers on the ground to trouble-shoot the cause of the degradation. Due to time constrains the task to relocate the STEAL-1 cargo boom was canceled for this EVA.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition28/russian_eva29.html|title=Cosmonauts Wrap Up Spacewalk|publisher=NASA|author=NASA|date=August 4, 2011|accessdate=July 29, 2012}} |} ==2012== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | | scope="col" width="100" |
'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" |
'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" |
'''Duration''' |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |162. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 30]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Kononenko]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Anton Shkaplerov]] | February 16, 2012
14:31 | February 16, 2012
20:46 | 6 hours, 15 minutes |- | colspan=4 |In preparation for the upcoming undocking of the [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]] the Strela 1 Equipment Crane was relocated from that module to the [[Mini-Research Module 2]]. In addition an experiment module which exposed materials to the space environment was retrieved while another experiment, the Vynoslivost Sample Experiment was installed on handrails on MRM2. Out of two hardware units for the TEST experiment, just one unit was installed before time for the EVA ran out. The scheduled task to install five shields on Zvezda to shield it from micrometeoroid debris was also cancelled and is rescheduled to be done during the next EVA.{{Cite web|url=http://www.spaceflight101.com/exp-30-eva-updates.html|title=ISS Expedition 30 - Spacewalk Updates|publisher=spaceflight101.com|first=Patrick|last=Blau|date=February 16, 2012|accessdate=July 28, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510043801/http://www.spaceflight101.com/exp-30-eva-updates.html|archivedate=May 10, 2015|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/605284main_Expedition_30_31_Press_Kit.pdf|title=Space Station Mission Expedition 30-31 Press Kit November 2011|publisher=NASA|author=NASA|date=November 2011|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |163. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 32]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Gennady Padalka]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Yuri Malenchenko]] | August 20, 2012
15:37 | August 20, 2012
21:28 | 5 hours, 51 minutes |- | colspan=4 |During this spacewalk the Strela 2 telescoping boom was relocated from the [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]] to the [[Zarya (ISS module)|''Zarya'' control module]] in preparation for the upcoming undocking of Pirs which paves the way for the arrival of the new Russian [[Nauka (ISS module)|Multipurpose Laboratory Module]] in 2013. The second task was to install micrometeoroid debris shields on the [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'' service module]]. Additionally a small satellite was deployed which is used by ground controllers to perform tracking tests used to help tracking actual space debris. Last but not least the spacewalkers added support struts to an airlock ladder and retrieved a Biorisk sample container. Retrieving another example container of a material exposure experiment failed due to a stuck hinge that prevented it from folding close. {{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/667038main_iss_exp32_33_34_pk.pdf|title=Space Station Mission Expedition 32-33-34 Press Kit July 2012|publisher=NASA|author=NASA|date=July 2012|accessdate=July 28, 2012}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition32/exp32_eva1.html|title=Cosmonauts Complete First Expedition 32 Spacewalk|publisher=NASA|author=NASA|date=August 20, 2012|accessdate=August 30, 2012}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.space.com/17197-spacewalk-cosmonauts-throw-satellite-into-space.html|title= Space Station Cosmonauts Toss Satellite Overboard in Spacewalk|publisher=Space.com|first=Tariq|last=Malik|date=August 20, 2012|accessdate=August 30, 2012}} |- | scope="row" rowspan=2 |164. |rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 32]]
EVA 2 | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]]
{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Akihiko Hoshide]] | August 30, 2012
12:16 | August 30, 2012
20:33 | 8 hours, 17 minutes |- | colspan=4 |The main objective for this EVA is to replace the Main Bus Switching Unit (MBSU) 1 which showed preliminary indications of failure in October 2011 with a replacement unit. Furthermore, in preparation of the integration of the new Russian module (the [[Nauka (ISS module)|Multipurpose Laboratory Module]]), some cables will be routed. If time permits, debris and thermal covers will be installed on [[PMA-2]]. {{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/667038main_iss_exp32_33_34_pk.pdf|title=Space Station Mission Expedition 32-33-34 Press Kit July 2012|publisher=NASA|author=NASA|date=July 2012|accessdate=July 29, 2012}} |- | rowspan=2 |165. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 32]]
EVA 3
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]]
{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Akihiko Hoshide]] | September 5, 2012
11:06 | September 5, 2012
17:34 | 6 hours, 28 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Installed the new MBSU unit, working around difficulty with one of the bolts; replaced one of the cameras mounted on the [[CanadArm]]. During this spacewalk, Sunita Williams broke [[Peggy Whitson]]'s record for most total time spacewalking by a woman. |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |166. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 33]]
EVA 1
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Sunita Williams]]
{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Akihiko Hoshide]] | November 1, 2012
12:29 | November 1, 2012
19:07 | 6 hours, 38 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Reconfigured and isolated a leak in the ammonia cooling system of power channel 2B on the P6 truss by-passing a leaking cooling loop and re-connecting jumpers to an unused loop of the Early External Thermal Control System (EETCS), and by re-deploying the trailing Thermal Control Radiator of the system. |} ==2013== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | | scope="col" width="100" align="center"|'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" align="center"|'''Duration''' |- | rowspan=2 |167. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 35]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Pavel Vinogradov]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Roman Romanenko]] | April 19, 2013
14:03 | April 19, 2013
20:41 | 6 hours, 38 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Installed the ''Obstanovka'' plasma waves and ionosphere experiment to the exterior of the ''Zvezda'' service module. Also replaced a faulty retro-reflector device used as navigational aids for the [[Automatic Transfer Vehicle]] and retrieved the ''Biorisk'' microbe exposure experiment. An attempt to retrieve the ''Vinoslivost'' materials sample experiment failed when it was accidentally dropped while being taken back to the ''Pirs'' module airlock.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/04/cosmonauts-russian-spacewalk-iss-rs32/|title=Cosmonauts successfully conclude Russian spacewalk|first=Pete|last=Harding|date=2013-04-19|accessdate=2013-04-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition35/eva_041913.html|title=Spacewalkers Deploy Plasma Experiment, Install Navigational Aid|author=NASA|date=2013-04-19|accessdate=2013-04-19}} |- |- | rowspan=2 |168. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 35]]
EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Thomas Marshburn]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Christopher Cassidy]] | May 11, 2013
12:44 | May 11, 2013
18:14 | 5 hours, 30 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Known as US EVA 21. Inspected and replaced a [[:File:PFCS .png|Pump Flow Control Subassembly]] on the station's [[Integrated truss structure#P6.2C S6 trusses|P6 truss]] which was leaking ammonia coolant. This was the same leaking thermal system from US EVA 20, performed on 1 November 2012.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/12/science/space/astronauts-replace-a-pump-hoping-to-stop-leak.html?hp|author=THE ASSOCIATED PRESS|date=May 11, 2013|accessdate=May 11, 2013|title=Astronauts Go in Search of an Ammonia Leak}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition35/e35_051113_eva.html|author=NASA|date=May 11, 2013|accessdate=May 11, 2013|title=Astronauts Complete Spacewalk to Repair Ammonia Leak}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |169. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 36]]
EVA 1
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Fyodor Yurchikhin]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexander Misurkin]] | June 24, 2013
13:32 | June 24, 2013
20:06 | 6 hours, 34 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Replaced a fluid flow regulator on the ''Zarya'' module, testing of the [[Kurs (docking system)|Kurs docking system]] on the station ahead of the arrival of a new Russian module, installing the "Indicator" experiment, installing gap spanners on to the outside of the station and photographing the multilayer insulation (MLI) protecting the Russian segment from micrometeoroids and taking samples from the exterior surface of the pressure hull underneath the MLI to identify signs of pressure hull material microscopic deterioration.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/06/rs-33-russian-duo-iss-spacewalk/|title=Russian duo complete ambitious ISS spacewalk|first=Chris|last=Bergin|date=2013-06-24|accessdate=2013-06-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/expeditions/expedition36/e36_062413_eva.html|title=Cosmonauts Complete Spacewalk to Prepare Station for New Russian Lab|author=NASA|date=2013-06-24|accessdate=2013-06-25}} |- | rowspan=2 |170. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 36]]
EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Christopher Cassidy]]
{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Luca Parmitano]] | July 9, 2013
12:02 | July 9, 2013
18:09 | 6 hours, 7 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Known as US EVA 22. Replaced a failed Space-to-Ground Transmitter Receiver Controller and the Mobile Base Camera Light Pan-Tilt Assembly, retrieved the MISSE-8 and ORMatE-III experiments, photographed the [[Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer|AMS-02]], moved two Radiator Grapple Bars to either sides of the truss, routed power cables to support the addition of the new Russian [[Multipurpose Laboratory Module|MLM]] and installed a multi-layer insulation cover to protect the docking interface of [[Pressurized Mating Adapter|PMA-2]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/07/eva-22-cassidy-parmitano-iss-spacewalk-eva-22/|first=Chris|last=Bergin |date=2013-07-09|title=EVA-22: Cassidy and Parmitano complete ISS spacewalk |accessdate=2013-07-10}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/July-9-station-spacewalk/|title=Station Astronauts Complete First of Two July Spacewalks|author=NASA |date=2013-07-09 |accessdate=2013-07-10}} |- | rowspan=2 |171. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 36]]
EVA 3
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Christopher Cassidy]]
{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Luca Parmitano]] | July 16, 2013
11:57 | July 16, 2013
13:29 | 1 hour, 32 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Known as US EVA 23. Installed a Y-bypass jumper on power lines on the Z1 truss, routing 1553 data cables for a grapple fixture and Ethernet cables for a future Russian station module. The spacewalk was then cut short after Parmitano reported excess water leaking inside his helmet.{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/21970-nasa-aborts-spacewalk-spacesuit-water-leak.html|first=Miriam|last=Kramer |date=2013-07-16 |title=NASA Cuts Spacewalk Short After Water Leak Inside Astronaut's Spacesuit |accessdate=2013-07-16}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/07/astronaut-duo-us-spacewalk-outside-iss/|first=Pete|last=Harding |date=2013-07-16 |title=EVA-23 terminated due to Parmitano EMU issue |accessdate=2013-07-17}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/tuesday-spacewalk-ended-early/index.html|author=NASA |date=2013-07-16 |title=Tuesday Spacewalk Ended Early |accessdate=2013-07-17}} |- | rowspan=2 |172. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 36]]
EVA 4
* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Fyodor Yurchikhin]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexander Misurkin]] | August 16, 2013
14:36 | August 16, 2013
22:05 | 7 hours, 29 minutes |- | colspan=4 | The cosmonauts successfully unreeled and routed two long power lines and an ethernet cable along the outside of the Zarya storage module that will be connected to the new Nauka laboratory after its arrival next year. Misurkin also mounted a space exposure experiment pallet on a handrail outside the upper Poisk module. The cosmonauts extended a telescoping space crane early on to help move large cable reels from Pirs to Zarya It was the 172nd EVA and with the seven-hour 29-minute duration set a new Russian spacewalk record, eclipsing the old mark of seven hours and 16 minutes set by two cosmonauts outside the Mir space station in July 1990.{{cite web |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/station/exp36/130816eva/|first=WILLIAM|last=HARWOOD |date=2013-08-16 |title=Cosmonauts set new Russian spacewalk endurance record |accessdate=2013-08-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/08/russian-eva-emu-troubleshooting-continues/|title=Russian EVA breaks record – EMU troubleshooting continues|first=Chris|last=Bergin|date=2013-08-16|accessdate=2013-08-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/spacewalkers-wire-up-station-for-future-lab/index.html|title=Spacewalkers Wire Up Station for Future Lab|author=NASA|date=2013-08-16|accessdate=2013-08-16}} |- | rowspan=2 |173. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 36]]

{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexander Misurkin]] | August 22, 2013

17:32 | 5 hours, 58 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Removed a laser communication and installed an EVA work station and camera pointing platform outside the Zvezda service module, inspection and tightening of various antenna covers on Zvezda, and installed new spacewalk aids.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/08/russian-duo-spacewalk-luca-recalls-eva-drama/|title=Russian duo complete EVA-35 – Luca recalls EVA drama|first=Chris|last=Bergin|date=2013-08-22|accessdate=2013-08-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/expedition-36-spacewalk-22-aug-2013/index.html|title=Spacewalkers Install Camera Platform, Inspect Station|author=NASA|date=2013-08-22|accessdate=2013-08-22}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |174. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 37]]

* | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Kotov]]
{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Ryazansky|Sergei Ryazanski]] | November 9, 2013
14:34 | November 9, 2013
20:24 | 5 hours, 50 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Took the Olympic torch for the [[2014 Winter Olympic Games]] to the outside of ISS. They also continued work on an extravehicular activity workstation and biaxial pointing platform by removing launch brackets and bolts, as well as retrieving an experimental package. The planned installation of a foot restraint on the mounting seat of the workstation was deferred to a future spacewalk after the spacewalkers noticed some issues with its alignment.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/11/russian-eva-olympic-torch-relay-space/|title=Troublesome ISS EVA conducts Olympic torch relay in space|first=Chris|last=Bergin|date=2013-11-09|accessdate=2013-11-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/olympic-torch-highlights-station-spacewalk/|title=Olympic Torch Highlights Station Spacewalk|author=NASA|date=2013-11-09|accessdate=2013-11-11}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |175. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 38]]
EVA 1
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard Mastracchio]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael S. Hopkins]] | December 21, 2013
12:01 | December 21, 2013
17:29 | 5 hours, 28 minutes |- | colspan="4" | The first of multiple spacewalks needed after cooling line temperatures decreased due to a stuck internal valve, which led to the deterioration of an ammonia pump module. The astronauts took the module out of the Active Thermal Control System's Loop A. They also connected two ammonia fluid lines to a jumper box after disconnecting them from the pump module. Two other lines were disconnected and stowed inside a thermal blanket.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/spacewalkers-remove-degraded-ammonia-pump/index.html|title=Spacewalkers Remove Degraded Ammonia Pump|author=NASA|date=2013-12-21|accessdate=2013-12-21}} |- | rowspan=2 |176. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 38]]

| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael S. Hopkins]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard Mastracchio]] | December 24, 2013
11:53 | December 24, 2013
19:23 | 7 hours, 30 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Retrieved spare ammonia pump module, installed it on starboard truss, and connected it to Loop A of Active Thermal Control System.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/astronauts-work-to-install-ammonia-pump-module-on-second-spacewalk/index.html|title=Spacewalkers Complete Installation of Ammonia Pump Module|author=NASA|date=2013-12-24|accessdate=2013-12-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.space.com/24079-space-station-astronauts-christmas-eve-spacewalk.html|title= Spacewalking Astronauts Gift Space Station with Christmas Eve Cooling Pump Fix|author=Robert Z. Pearlman|date=2013-12-24|accessdate=2013-12-24}} |- | rowspan=2 |177. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 38]]

Also installed and jettisoned experimental equipment outside the Russian segment. Longest Russian EVA in history.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/station-cosmonauts-complete-spacewalk-to-deploy-cameras/index.html|title=Station Cosmonauts Complete Spacewalk to Deploy Cameras|author=NASA|date=2013-12-27|accessdate=2013-12-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2013/12/russian-eva-install-commercial-cameras/|title= Russian duo break EVA record – Main task suffers issue|first=Chris|last=Bergin|date=2013-12-27|accessdate=2013-12-28}} |} ==2014== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ccccff" | | scope="col" width="100" align="center"|'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" align="center"|'''Duration''' |- | rowspan=2 |178. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 38]]

14:10 | June 19, 2014
21:33 | 7 hours 23 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Installed an automated phased antenna array used for the Russian command and telemetry system, relocated a part of the Obstanovka experiment that monitors charged particles and plasma in Low Earth Orbit, verifying the correct installation of the universal work platform (URM-D), taking samples from one of Zvezda's windows, and jettisoning an experiment frame.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/spacewalkers-complete-installation-and-experiment-work/|title=Spacewalkers Complete Installation and Experiment Work|author=|publisher=NASA|date=2014-06-19|accessdate=2014-06-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/06/eva-38-russian-duo-spacewalk/|title= EVA-38: Frustration morphs into success during Russian spacewalk|first=David|last=Štula|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|date=2014-06-19|accessdate=2014-06-20}} |- | rowspan=2 |181. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 40]]

19:13 | 5 hours 11 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Released [[Chasqui-1]] cubesat into space; installed experiment packages (EXPOSE-R2 biological experiment, Plume Impingement and Deposit Monitoring unit), retrieved experiments (Vinoslivost materials exposure panel, Biorisk biological experiment), replaced cassette on SKK experiment and attached a handrail on an antenna.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/content/station-spacewalkers-deploy-nanosatellite-install-and-retrieve-science/index.html|title=Station Spacewalkers Deploy Nanosatellite, Install and Retrieve Science|author=|publisher=NASA|date=2014-08-18|accessdate=2014-08-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/08/russian-spacewalkers-perform-science-oriented-eva/|title= Russian spacewalkers successfully complete science-oriented EVA|author=David Štula and Chris Bergin|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|date=2014-08-18|accessdate=2014-08-18}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |182. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 41]]

19:51 | 5 hours 31 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Installed gap spanners on the hull of the station for facilitating movement of crew members on future spacewalks, cleaned windows of the Zvezda Service Module, install fasteners on communications antennas, replaced an aging docking antenna, photographed various locations and hardware on Zvezda and nearby modules, and retrieved a space environment experiment.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.nasa.gov/spacestation/2015/08/10/cosmonauts-complete-russian-spacewalk/|title=Cosmonauts Complete Russian Spacewalk|author=|publisher=NASA|date=2015-08-10|accessdate=2015-08-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/08/rs-41-cosmonaut-only-russian-spacewalk-2015/|title=RS-41: Cosmonaut duo complete the only Russian spacewalk of 2015|first=David|last=Štula|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|date=2015-08-10|accessdate=2015-08-11}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |189. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 45]]

12:03 | October 28, 2015
19:19 | 7 hours 16 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Applied a thermal cover on the [[Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer]]; lubricating one of the latching ends of the Canadarm2 robotic arm; and began work to connect power and data system cables for the future installation of docking adapters for future US crew vehicles.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.nasa.gov/spacestation/2015/10/28/nasa-astronauts-complete-their-first-spacewalk/|title=NASA Astronauts Complete Their First Spacewalk|first=Mark|last=Garcia|publisher=NASA|date=2015-10-28|accessdate=2015-10-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/10/astronauts-housekeeping-eva-32-outside-iss/|title=EVA-32: Astronauts complete seven hour spacewalk|first=Pete|last=Harding|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|date=2015-10-28|accessdate=2015-10-28}} |- | rowspan=2 |190. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 45]]

{{flagicon|USA}} [[Scott Kelly (astronaut)|Scott Kelly]] | November 6, 2015
11:22 | November 6, 2015
19:10 | 7 hours 48 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Worked to restore a portion of the ISS's cooling system to its primary configuration, returning ammonia coolant levels to normal in the primary and backup radiator arrays.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.nasa.gov/spacestation/2015/11/06/pair-of-nasa-astronauts-wrap-up-second-spacewalk/|title=Pair of NASA Astronauts Wrap Up Second Spacewalk|first=Mark|last=Garcia|publisher=NASA|date=2015-11-06|accessdate=2015-11-06}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/11/astronauts-spacewalk-reconfigure-solar-array-cooling-system/|title=Astronauts complete EVA-33 spacewalk to reconfigure solar array cooling system|first=Pete|last=Harding|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|date=2015-11-06|accessdate=2015-11-06}} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |191. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 46]]

| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Scott Kelly (astronaut)|Scott Kelly]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Timothy Kopra]] | December 21, 2015
13:45 | December 21, 2015
16:01 | 3 hours 16 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Kelly and Kopra performed an EVA to troubleshoot the starboard Crew Equipment Translation Aid (CETA) cart and Mobile Transporter (MT). The starboard CETA cart is linked to the side of the Mobile Transporter (MT), and its brake was engaged preventing MT movement. Kelly released the brake and the MT was successfully commanded by Robotic Ground Controllers to translate to Worksite 4 where it was latched and mated. In addition to the CETA cart task, Kelly and Kopra performed several get ahead activities. Kelly routed Pressurized Mating Adapter (PMA) 3 power and International Docking Adapter (IDA) ethernet cables along Node 1. Kopra opened the Secondary Power Distribution Assembly (SPDA) doors for future Robotic operations, routed an ethernet cable for the Multipurpose Laboratory Module (MLM), and retrieved a Scoop/D-Handle tool from a toolbox on the truss.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.nasa.gov/stationreport/2015/12/21/|title=ISS Daily Summary Report – 12/21/15|author=NASA|publisher=NASA.gov|date=2015-12-21|accessdate=2015-12-21}} |- |} ==2016== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#cfccfc" | | scope="col" width="100" align="center"|'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" align="center"|'''Duration''' |- | rowspan=2 |192. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 46]]

{{flagicon|GB}} [[Tim Peake]] | January 15, 2016
12:48 | January 15, 2016
17:31 | 4 hours 43 minutes |- | colspan=4 | Replaced 1B Shunt unit, continued installation of IDA cables. The EVA was terminated early when Kopra reported the formation of a small bubble of water inside his helmet. The main objective, replacing the SSU, was completed successfully.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/01/astronauts-iss-power-channel-first-spacewalk-uk/|title=Astronauts repair ISS power Channel – first spacewalk for UK ends early|first=Pete|last=Harding|publisher=NASASpaceflight.com|date=2016-01-15|accessdate=2015-01-17}} |- | rowspan=2 |193. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 46]]

{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Alexandrovich Volkov|Sergey Volkov]] | February 3, 2016
12:55 | February 3, 2016
17:40 |4 hours 45 minutes |- | colspan=4 |Conducted the ‘Test’ experiment by gathering samples on different locations (the hatch of Pirs, Window #8 on Zvezda) and taking engineering photos of various areas on the aft segment of ISS, jettisoned a bundle containing a flash drive holding video messages from last year's 70th anniversary celebration of Victory Day, retrieved the EXPOSE-R astrobiology experiment, collected the CKK 2-M2 experiment cassette and replaced it with the CKK 3-M3 cassette, configured a plume-sensing payload, installed the Vinoslivost payload (another space exposure experiment) installed gap spanners on the Russian segment, and retrieved the "Restavratsiya" (Restoration) Experiment Hardware, gathering experience in the in-space application of adhesive surface coatings for future operational use in space-based repairs of external equipment.{{Cite web|url = http://spaceflight101.com/iss/russian-eva-42-success/|title = Cosmonauts check off all Objectives in Experiment-Oriented Spacewalk|date = |access-date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} |- | colspan=7 bgcolor=#ccccff height="5px" | |- | rowspan=2 |194. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 48]]

| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jeffrey Williams (astronaut)|Jeff Williams]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Kate Rubins]] | August 19, 2016
13:04 | August 19, 2016

EVA 2
| {{flagicon|USA}} [[Jeffrey Williams (astronaut)|Jeff Williams]]
{{flagicon|USA}} [[Kate Rubins]] | September 1, 2016
11:53 | September 1, 2016
17:41 |6 hours 48 minutes |- | colspan="4" |The main objective of this EVA was to retract a thermal radiator on the port truss. This radiator was supposed to be retracted during Expedition 45 EVA 2 (November 6, 2015) but was not completed. The radiator had been deployed on Expedition 33 EVA 1 (November 1, 2012) in an attempt to isolate a coolant leak. Additional completed tasks included installing HD Video Cameras on the port/outboard side of the station (one zenith, one nadir), applying additional torque to [[Integrated Truss Structure#Solar alpha rotary joint|SARJ]] bolts, photographing the inside of the SARJ, tying back a protective blanket covering hardware which will be robotically manipulated later, and tying back Crew and Equipment Translation Aid (CETA) Cart brake handles to keep them out of the SARJ rotation envelope.{{Cite web|url=http://spaceflight101.com/iss-expedition-48/iss-us-eva-37-preview/|title=ISS Spacewalkers to retract Thermal Radiator, Install HD Video Camera|date= |access-date= |website=spaceflight101.com/ |last= |first= }}{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2016/09/eva-37-first-external-hd-camera-ttcr-retract/|title=EVA-37 installs first external HD cameras and conducts TTCR retract task {{!}} NASASpaceFlight.com|website=www.nasaspaceflight.com|access-date=2016-10-19}}{{Citation|last=Julian Danzer|title=ISS U.S. Spacewalk #37 Expedition 48 NASA TV Preview Briefing|date=2016-08-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qhyqFITE51w|accessdate=2016-10-19}} |} ==2017== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#cfccfc" | | scope="col" width="100" align="center"|'''Mission''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Spacewalkers''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''Start ([[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]])''' | scope="col" width="300" align="center"|'''End (UTC)''' | scope="col" width="175" align="center"|'''Duration''' |- | rowspan=2 |196. | rowspan=2 |[[Expedition 50]]

Spacewalk suffered a 7-minute delay because of a water leak which formed ice crystals inside the airlock. |- | colspan="6" bgcolor="#ccccff" height="5px" | |- |rowspan="2"|211 |rowspan="2"|[[Expedition 56]]
EVA 1 |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Andrew J. Feustel]] {{flagicon|USA}} [[Richard R. Arnold]] |June 14, 2018 12:06 |June 14, 2018 18:55 |6 hours 49 minutes |- | colspan="4" |Feustel and Arnold installed new high-definition cameras near [[IDA-2|IDA 2]] mated to the front end of the station's Harmony module. The additions will provide enhanced views during the final phase of approach and docking of the [[SpaceX Crew Dragon]] and [[Boeing CST-100 Starliner|Boeing CST 100 Starliner]] commercial crew spacecraft that will soon begin launching from American soil. The astronauts also swapped out a camera assembly on the starboard truss of the station used to film [[NASA TV]] and closed an aperture door on the [[Cloud Aerosol Transport System|CATS]] experiment outside the Japanese [[Kibo (ISS module)|Kibo]] module in preparation for disposal on [[SpaceX CRS-15|SpaceX CRS 15]] and replacement by its successor, [[ECOSTRESS]]. Get aheads involved relocating an adjustable grapple bar to the S1 Truss and securing the Flex Hose Rotary Coupler in preparation for replacement on the next spacewalk. During the spacewalk Feustel beat [[Jerry L. Ross|Jerry Ross]], his [[STS-125|STS 125]] crewmate [[John M. Grunsfeld|Dr. John Grunsfeld]], [[Fyodor Yurchikhin|Fyoder Yurchikhin]], and [[Peggy Whitson]] to become third on the list of all time space walkers. {{Cite web|https://blogs.nasa.gov/spacestation/2018/06/14/spacewalkers-complete-hd-camera-installation-work/ |- | rowspan="2" |212 |rowspan="2"|[[Expedition 56]]
EVA 2* |{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Oleg Artemyev]] {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Prokopyev (cosmonaut)|Sergey Prokopyev]] |August 15, 2018 16:17 |August 15, 2018 00:03 |7 hours 46 minutes |- | colspan="4" |The cosmonauts launched four cubesats and installed the Icarus experiment. Spacewalk fell behind schedule when Icarus failed to seat properly putting the spacewalk 90 minutes behind schedule and calling for an hour extension. The cosmonauts finished the spacewalk by retrieving experiments from the [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]] and [[Poisk (ISS module)|''Poisk'' module]] {{Cite web|http://www.orbital-velocity.com/news/2018/8/16/russian-spacewalk-runs-into-overtime-during-icarus-experiment-installation/ |} *denotes spacewalks performed from the [[Pirs (ISS module)|''Pirs'' docking compartment]] in Russian [[Orlan space suit|Orlan]] suits.
^denotes spacewalks performed from the [[Poisk (ISS module)|''Poisk'' module]] in Russian Orlan suits.
†denotes spacewalks performed from the visiting space shuttle's airlock.
‡denotes the one EVA and one IVA performed from the transfer compartment at the forward end of the [[Zvezda (ISS module)|''Zvezda'']] Service Module.
All other spacewalks were performed from the [[Quest Joint Airlock|''Quest'' airlock]].
ISS Expedition spacewalks are separated from shuttle spacewalks by a separator. ==Gallery==

revision.comment: /* The operational architectonics theory of brain–mind */
revision.text:
In the field of [[computational neuroscience]], the theory of '''metastability''' refers to the [[human brain|human brain’s]] ability to integrate several functional parts and to produce [[neural oscillations]] in a cooperative and coordinated manner, providing the basis for [[consciousness|conscious]] activity.
Metastability, a state in which signals (such as oscillatory waves) fall outside their natural equilibrium state but persist for an extended period of time, is a principle that describes the brain’s ability to make sense out of seemingly random environmental cues. In the past 25 years, interest in metastability and the underlying framework of [[nonlinear dynamics]] has been fueled by advancements in the methods by which computers model brain activity.
== Overview ==
<!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:metastability_concepts_diagram.gif|thumbnail|350px|right|A schematic illustrating how metastability links neurons to neural networks]] -->
[[EEG]] measures the gross electrical activity of the brain that can be observed on the surface of the skull. In the metastability theory, EEG outputs produce oscillations that can be described as having identifiable patterns that correlate with each other at certain [[frequencies]]. Each [[neuron]] in a [[neuronal network]] normally outputs a dynamical oscillatory waveform, but also has the ability to output a [[chaos theory|chaotic]] waveform.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Information processing using stable and unstable oscillations: a tutorial|journal=Cellular Neural Networks and their Applications|date=1994-12-18|first=P|last=Thiran|author2=M Hasler|volume=|issue=|pages=127–136|id= |url=|doi=10.1109/cnna.1994.381695}}</ref> When neurons are integrated into the neural network by interfacing neurons with each other, the dynamical oscillations created by each neuron can be combined to form highly predictable EEG oscillations.
By identifying these correlations and the individual neurons that contribute to predictable EEG oscillations, scientists can determine which [[Cerebral cortex|cortical domains]] are processing in parallel and which neuronal networks are intertwined. In many cases, metastability describes instances in which distal parts of the brain interact with each other to respond to environmental stimuli.
== Frequency domains of metastability ==
It has been suggested that one integral facet of brain dynamics underlying conscious thought is the brain’s ability to convert seemingly [[electronic noise|noisy]] or chaotic signals into predictable oscillatory patterns.<ref name=rhythmsofthebrain/>
In EEG oscillations of neural networks, neighboring waveform frequencies are correlated on a [[logarithmic scale]] rather than a [[linear]] scale. As a result, mean frequencies in oscillatory bands cannot link together according to linearity of their mean frequencies. Instead, [[phase transitions]] are linked according to their ability to couple with adjacent [[phase shifts]] in a constant state of transition between unstable and stable phase [[synchronization]].<ref name=rhythmsofthebrain>{{cite book | last = Buzsáki | first = György | title = Rhythms of the Brain | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2006 | location = U.S. | pages = 128–31 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-19-530106-4 }}</ref> This phase synchronization forms the basis of metastable behavior in neural networks.
Metastable behavior occurs at the [[high frequency]] domain known as [[pink noise|'''''1/f regime''''']]. This regime describes an environment in which a noisy signal (also known as [[pink noise]]) has been induced, where the amount of [[Power (physics)|power]] the signal outputs over a certain [[Bandwidth (signal processing)|bandwidth]] (its [[power spectral density]]) is inversely proportional to its frequency.
Noise at the ''1/f'' regime can be found in many biological systems – for instance, in the output of a heartbeat in an [[ECG]] waveform—but serves a unique purpose for phase synchrony in neuronal networks. At the ''1/f'' regime, the brain is in the critical state necessary for a conscious response to weak or chaotic environmental signals because it can shift the random signals into identifiable and predictable oscillatory waveforms.<ref name=rhythmsofthebrain/> While often transient, these waveforms exist in a stable form long enough to contribute to what can be thought of as conscious response to environmental stimuli.
==Theories of metastability==
===Oscillatory activity and coordination dynamics===
The [[dynamical system]] model, which represents networks composed of integrated neural systems communicating with one another between unstable and stable phases, has become an increasingly popular theory underpinning the understanding of metastability.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Making complexity simpler: Multivariability and metastability in the brain.|journal=International Journal of Neuroscience|year=2004|first=A.|last=Fingelkurts|author2=A. Fingelkurts|volume=114|issue= 7|pages=843–862|doi= 10.1080/00207450490450046|pmid=15204050|url=|format=PDF|accessdate=}}</ref> Coordination dynamics forms the basis for this dynamical system model by describing mathematical formulae and paradigms governing the coupling of environmental stimuli to their effectors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ccs.fau.edu/html_old/coordlab.htm |title=Laboratory for Coordination Dynamics - Center for Complex Systems and Brain Sciences |accessdate=2007-11-27 |work= Florida Atlantic University }}</ref>
==== History of coordination dynamics and the Haken-Kelso-Bunz (HKB) model ====
The so-named HKB model is one of the earliest and well-respected theories to describe coordination dynamics in the brain. In this model, the formation of neural networks can be partly described as [[self-organization]], where individual neurons and small neuronal systems aggregate and coordinate to either adapt or respond to local stimuli or to divide labor and [[Specialization (functional)|specialize]] in function.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Self-organization in sensor networks.|journal=J. Parallel and Distributed Computing|date= July 2004|first=T.|last=Collier|author2=Charles Taylor|volume=64|issue=7|pages=866–873|doi= 10.1016/j.jpdc.2003.12.004|url=http://www.isrl.uiuc.edu/~amag/langev/paper/collier04sensorNetworks.html|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-11-26}}</ref>
[[File:Self-Organization in Brain Fig1.png|thumbnail|350px|right|Transition of parallel movement of index fingers to antiparallel, symmetric movement.]]
In the last 20 years,{{When|date=January 2018}} the HKB model has become a widely accepted theory to explain the coordinated movements and behaviors of individual neurons into large, end-to-end neural networks. Originally the model described a system in which spontaneous transitions observed in finger movements could be described as a series of in-phase and out-of-phase movements.<ref name=hkbmodelrevisited>{{cite journal|title=The HKB model revisited: How varying the degree of symmetry controls dynamics|journal=Human Movement Science|year=2000|first=A. |last=Fuchs|author2=V.K. Jirsa|volume=19|issue=4|pages=425–449|id= |url=|doi=10.1016/S0167-9457(00)00025-7 }}</ref>
In the mid-1980s HKB model experiments, subjects were asked to wave one finger on each hand in two modes of direction: first, known as out of phase, both fingers moving in the same direction back and forth (as windshield wipers might move); and second, known as in-phase, where both fingers come together and move away to and from the midline of the body. To illustrate coordination dynamics, the subjects were asked to move their fingers out of phase with increasing speed until their fingers were moving as fast as possible. As movement approached its critical speed, the subjects’ fingers were found to move from out-of-phase (windshield-wiper-like) movement to in-phase (toward midline movement).
The HKB model, which has also been elucidated by several complex mathematical descriptors, is still a relatively simple but powerful way to describe seemingly-independent systems that come to reach synchrony just before a state of [[self-organized criticality]].<ref name=hkbmodelrevisited/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Dynamic pattern generation in behavioral and neural systems|journal=Science|year=1988|first=J.A. Scott|last=Kelso|volume=239|issue=4847|pages=1513–1520|doi= 10.1126/science.3281253|pmid=3281253|display-authors=etal|url=|format=PDF|accessdate=}}</ref>
==== Evolution of cognitive coordination dynamics ====
In the last 10 years,{{When|date=January 2018}} the HKB model has been reconciled with advanced mathematical models and supercomputer-based computation to link rudimentary coordination dynamics to higher-order processes such as learning and memory.
The traditional EEG is still useful to investigate coordination between different parts of the brain. 40 Hz [[gamma wave]] activity is a prominent example of the brain’s ability to be modeled dynamically and is a common example of coordination dynamics. Continuous study of these and other oscillations has led to an important conclusion: analyzing waves as having a common signal phase but a different [[amplitude]] leads to the possibility that these different signals serve a [[synergistic]] function.<ref name=metastabilitycriticality>{{cite journal|title=Metastability, criticality and phase transitions in brain and its models|journal=Biosystems|date=September 2007|first=A. G.|last=Werner|author2=V.K. Jirsa|volume=90|issue=2|pages=496–508|doi= 10.1016/j.biosystems.2006.12.001|pmid=17316974|url=|format=PDF|accessdate=}}</ref>
Some unusual characteristics of these waves: they are virtually simultaneous and have a very short onset latency, which implies that they operate faster than [[chemical synapse|synaptic conduction]] would allow; and that their recognizable patterns are sometimes interrupted by periods of [[randomness]]. The latter idiosyncrasy has served as the basis for assuming an interaction and transition between neural subsystems. Analysis of activation and deactivation of regions of the cortex has shown a dynamic shift between dependence and [[interdependence]], reflecting the brain's ''metastable'' nature as a function of a coordinated dynamical system.
[[fMRI]], [[electrode array|large-scale electrode arrays]], and [[Magnetoencephalography|MEG]] expand upon the patterns seen in EEG by providing visual confirmation of coordinated dynamics. The MEG, which provides an improvement over EEG in spatiotemporal characterization, allows researchers to stimulate certain parts of the brain with environmental cues and observe the response in a [[holism in science|holistic brain model]]. Additionally, MEG has a response time of about one [[millisecond]], allowing for a virtually real-time investigation of the active turning-on and -off of selected parts of the brain in response to environmental cues and conscious tasks.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Connecting Cortical and behavioral dynamics: bimanual coordination|journal=Neural Computation|date=November 1998|first=V.K.|last=Jirsa |author2=A. Fuchs |author3=J.A.S. Kelso |volume=10|issue=8|pages=2019–2045|doi= 10.1162/089976698300016954|pmid=9804670|url=|format=PDF|accessdate=}}</ref>
==== Social coordination dynamics and the phi complex ====
A developing field in coordination dynamics involves the theory of social coordination, which attempts to relate the DC to normal human development of complex [[social interaction|social cues]] following certain patterns of interaction. This work is aimed at understanding how human social interaction is mediated by metastability of neural networks. fMRI and EEG are particularly useful in mapping thalamocortical response to social cues in experimental studies.
A new theory called the [[phi complex]] has been developed by [[J. A. Scott Kelso]] and fellow researchers at [[Florida Atlantic University]] to provide experimental results for the theory of social coordination dynamics.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The phi complex as a neuromarker of human social coordination|journal=PNAS|date=March 2007|first=E|last=Tognoli|volume=104|issue=19|pages=8190–8195|id= |url=|doi=10.1073/pnas.0611453104|pmid=17470821|pmc=1859993 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> In Kelso's experiments, two subjects were separated by an opaque barrier and asked to wag their fingers; then the barrier was removed and the subjects were instructed to continue to wag their fingers as if no change had occurred. After a short period, the movements of the two subjects sometimes became coordinated and synchronized (but other times continued to be asynchronous). The link between EEG and conscious social interaction is described as Phi, one of several brain rhythms operating in the 10 Hz range. Phi consists of two components: one to favor solitary behavior and another to favor interactive ([[interpersonal]]) behavior. Further analysis of Phi may reveal the social and interpersonal implications of [[degenerative diseases]] such as [[schizophrenia]]—or may provide insight into common social relationships such as the dynamics of [[alpha male|alpha and omega-males]] or the popular [[bystander effect]] describing how people diffuse personal responsibility in emergency situations depending on the number of other individuals present.
=== Dynamic core ===
A second theory of metastability involves a so-called '''dynamic core''', which is a term to loosely describe the thalamocortical region believed to be the integration center of [[consciousness]]. The dynamic core hypothesis (DCH) reflects the use and disuse of interconnected neuronal networks during stimulation of this region. A computer model of 65,000 [[spiking neuron]]s<ref name=metastabilitycriticality/> shows that neuronal groups existing in the cortex and [[thalamus]] interact in the form of synchronous oscillation. The interaction between distinct neuronal groups forms the dynamic core and may help explain the nature of conscious experience. A critical feature of the DCH is that instead of thinking binarily about transitions between neural integration and non-integration (i.e., that the two are either one or the other with no in-between), the metastable nature of the dynamic core can allow for a continuum of integration.<ref name=metastabilitycriticality/>
==== Neural Darwinism ====
<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[File:exp_sel.gif|right|frame|Experiental selection, a component of neural Darwinism, allows for the "re-wiring" of synapses according to their frequency of use in conscious behavior.]] -->
One theory used to integrate the dynamic core with conscious thought involves a developing concept known as [[neural Darwinism]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Neural Darwinism and consciousness|journal=Consciousness and Cognition|year=2005|first=A.|last=Seth|author2=B. Baars|volume=14|pages=140–168|doi=10.1016/j.concog.2004.08.008 }}</ref> In this model, metastable interactions in the thalamocortical region cause a process of selectionism through [[Neural Darwinism#Reentry|re-entry]] (a phenomenon describing the overall reciprocity and interactivity between signals in distant parts of the brain through coupled signal latency). Neuronal selectivity involves mechanochemical events that take place pre- and post-[[birth|natally]] whereby neuronal connections are influenced by environmental experiences.<ref>{{cite book | last = Edelman | first = Gerald | authorlink = Gerald Edelman | title = Neural Darwinism: The Theory of Neuronal Group Selection | publisher = Basic Books | year = 1987 | location = New York, New York | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-19-286089-5 }}</ref> The modification of synaptic signals as it relates to the dynamic core provides further explanation for the DCH.
Despite growing evidence for the DCH, the ability to generate mathematical constructs to model and predict dynamic core behavior has been slow to progress.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Disentangling the dynamic core: a research program for a neurodynamics at the large-scale|journal=Biol. Res.|year=2003|first=M.|last=Le Van Quyen|volume=36|issue=1|pages=67–88|id= |url=|pmid=12795207|doi=10.4067/s0716-97602003000100006}}</ref> Continued development of [[stochastic processes]] designed to graph neuronal signals as chaotic and non-linear has provided some algorithmic basis for analyzing how chaotic environmental signals are coupled to enhance selectivity of [[axon guidance|neural outgrowth]] or coordination in the dynamic core.
=== Global workspace hypothesis ===
The global workspace hypothesis is another theory to elucidate metastability, and has existed in some form since 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cogweb.ucla.edu/CogSci/Baars-update_03.html |title=An update on global workspace theory |accessdate=2007-11-26 |last=Baars |first=Bernard |date=October 2003 |work=Science and Consciousness Review }}</ref> This hypothesis also focuses on the phenomenon of re-entry, the ability of a routine or process to be used by multiple parts of the brain simultaneously.<ref name=metastabilitycriticality/> Both the DCH and global neuronal workspace (GNW) models involve re-entrance, but the GNW model elaborates on re-entrant connectivity between distant parts of the brain and long-range signal flow. Workspace neurons are similar anatomically but separated spatially from each other.
One interesting aspect of the GNW is that with sufficient intensity and length over which a signal travels, a small initiation signal can be compounded to activate an "ignition" of a critical spike-inducing state. This idea is analogous to a skier on the slope of a mountain, who, by disrupting a few blocks of ice with his skis, initiates a giant [[avalanche]] in his wake. To help prove the circuit-like amplification theory, research has shown that inducing [[lesions]] in long-distance connections corrupts performance in integrative models.<ref name=metastabilitycriticality/>
A popular experiment to demonstrate the global workspace hypothesis involves showing a subject a series of [[Backmasking|backward-masked visual words]] (e.g., ''"the dog sleeps quietly"'' is shown as ''"ylteiuq speels god eht"'') and then asking the subject to identify the forward "translation" of these words. Not only did fMRI detect activity in the word-recognition portion of the cortex, but additionally, activity is often detected in the [[parietal cortex|parietal]] and [[prefrontal cortex|prefrontal cortices]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Toward a cognitive neuroscience of consciousness: basic evidence and a workspace framework|journal=Cognition|year=2001|first=S.|last=DeHaene|author2=L. Naccache|volume=79|issue=1|pages=1–37|doi= 10.1016/S0010-0277(00)00123-2|pmid=11164022 }}</ref> In almost every experiment, conscious input in word and [[hearing (sense)|audition]] tasks shows a much wider use of integrated portions of the brain than in identical unconscious input. The wide distribution and constant signal transfer between different areas of the brain in experimental results is a common method to attempt to prove the neural workspace hypothesis. More studies are being conducted to determine precisely the correlation between conscious and unconscious task deliberation in the realm of the global workspace.
=== The operational architectonics theory of brain–mind ===
Although the concept of metastability has been around in Neuroscience for some time,<ref>[[J. A. Scott Kelso]] (1991) Behavioral and neural pattern generation: the concept of neurobehavioral dynamical system (NBDS). In: Koepchen HP (ed) Cardiorespiratory and motor coordination.Springer, Berlin Heidelberg New York.</ref> the specific interpretation of metastability in the context of brain operations of different complexity has been developed by Andrew and Alexander Fingelkurts within their model of [http://www.bm-science.com/team/art53.pdf Operational Architectonics of brain–mind functioning]. Metastability is basically a theory of how global integrative and local segregative tendencies coexist in the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bressler SL, Kelso JA | year = 2001 | title = Cortical coordination dynamics and cognition | url = | journal = Trends Cogn Sci | volume = 5 | issue = | pages = 26–36 | doi=10.1016/s1364-6613(00)01564-3}}</ref><ref>Kaplan AYa (1998) Nonstationary EEG: methodological and experimental analysis. Usp Fiziol Nauk (Success in Physiological Sciences) 29:35–55 (in Russian).</ref> The Operational Architectonics is centered on the fact that in the metastable regime of brain functioning, the individual parts of the brain exhibit tendencies to function autonomously at the same time as they exhibit tendencies for coordinated activity.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Fingelkurts AnA Fingelkurts AlA | year = 2001 | title = Operational architectonics of the human brain biopotential field: towards solving the mind~brain problem | url = | journal = Brain and Mind | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 261–296 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Fingelkurts AnA Fingelkurts AlA | year = 2004 | title = Making complexity simpler: multivariability and metastability in the Brain | url = | journal = Int J Neurosci | volume = 114 | issue = | pages = 843–862 | doi=10.1080/00207450490450046 | pmid=15204050}}</ref> In accordance with Operational Architectonics,<ref>[http://www.bm-science.com/team/chapt3.pdf Operational Architectonics]</ref> the synchronized operations produced by distributed neuronal assemblies constitute the metastable spatial-temporal patterns. They are metastable because intrinsic differences in the activity between neuronal assemblies are sufficiently large that they each do their own job (operation), while still retaining a tendency to be coordinated together in order to realize the complex brain operation.<ref>Fingelkurts AnA, Fingelkurts AlA (2005) Mapping of the brain operational architectonics. Chapter 2. In: Chen FJ (ed) Focus on brain mapping research. [[Nova Science Publishers, Inc.]], pp 59–98. URL = http://www.bm-science.com/team/chapt3.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Fingelkurts AnA Fingelkurts AnA | year = 2006 | title = Timing in cognition and EEG brain dynamics: discreteness versus continuity | url = | journal = Cogn Process | volume = 7 | issue = | pages = 135–162 | doi=10.1007/s10339-006-0035-0}}</ref>
== The future of metastability ==
In addition to study investigating the effects of metastable interactions on traditional social function, much research will likely focus on determining the role of the coordinated dynamic system and the global workspace in the progression of debilitating diseases such as [[Alzheimer's disease]], [[Parkinson's disease]], [[stroke]], and schizophrenia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ccs.fau.edu/section_links/HBBLv2/ |title=The Human Brain and Behavior Laboratory |accessdate=2007-11-26 |work=Center for Complex Systems and Brain Sciences - Florida Atlantic University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070923003852/http://www.ccs.fau.edu/section_links/HBBLv2/ |archivedate=2007-09-23 |df= }}</ref> Undoubtedly, spatiotemporal imaging techniques such as MEG and fMRI will elaborate on results already gleaned from analysis of EEG output.
An interest in the effect of a traumatic or semi-traumatic brain injury ([[traumatic brain injury|TBI]]) on the coordinated dynamical system has developed in the last five years as the number of TBI cases has risen from war-related injuries.
==See also== *[[Cognitive psychology]] *[[Electroencephalogram]]
